Ellen Page, star of Juno, stands alone on a street corner with a piece of cardboard held above her head, the unsettling message scribbled with Sharpie onto her sign. Burma, also known as Myanmar, is a Southeastern Asian country ruled by a tyrannical militant junta who came into power in 1962 through the act of a coup d’état. In 2007 a number of street protests occurred, the first public protests in a decade. Led by a large number of Burmese monks, these protests earned the name “The Saffron Revolution”, christened after the color of the robes that the monks wore. After the first few initial uprisings the public at large began taking an interest in the protests, and while at first the Burmese government begrudgingly allowed the monks to engage in peaceful gatherings, soon the violence escalated into what some considered an all-out war between the monks and the military junta, with the military actively invading and ransacking monasteries around the country. Foreign journalists were rounded up and imprisoned on sight, with a Japanese photojournalist named Kenji Nagai killed on September 27th, 2007, simply for being present at a street protest. While the official death toll rests at 13 killed, Colonel Hla Win, who defected from the army some days prior to the official report, is quoted as having said, “Many more people have been killed in recent days than you’ve heard about. The bodies can be counted in several thousand.”

This is nothing new. While these are some of the most recent examples of atrocities taking place in our world, a government’s desire to quash dissent and maintain complete rule over its citizenry has been around for as long as civilization itself. Early Roman emperors declared themselves chosen by the gods to have complete executive ruling over every aspect of their society. Japanese emperors are believed to actually be gods, sent to our world to lead their people to prosperity through the invention of Motorola cell phones and hara-kiri, and our current president, George W. Bush, has weekly conference calls with Ted Haggard, the leader of Stupid People Worldwide, a subsidiary group of the Republic Party.

Some of the most well known examples of these actions are such incidents as the 1989 June 4th protest at Tiananmen Square, where intellectuals, labor activists, and students all gathered to protest the authoritarian rule of the government. The death toll in that particular instance ranges wildly, with official reports from the Chinese government stating 200-300 dead to reports let out by the Chinese Red Cross, declaring between 2,000-3,000 dead.  Another is the Rwandan genocide of the 1990s, where Hutu militia groups, aided by the Rwandan government, began a systematic killing of all Tutsis, as well as political moderates, irrespective of their ethnic backgrounds. Hitler’s ‘Third Reich’, a period spanning several years and several countries where anyone of Jewish background was rounded up and killed, is another extreme example.

Duke Ellington’s legacy in jazz derives in large part from his longevity and, by extension, his creative abilities to shape his orchestra. Ellington’s presence on the piano is subtle in many of the compositions selected for this assignment, but as a composer Ellington excelled at creating rich and complex pieces that showcased the individual abilities of band members. Ellington crafted the framework in which a soloist could freely improvise, in addition to writing tightly orchestrated pieces and phrases that called on the particular style of band members to highlight musical ideas. In doing this, he also emphasized the tone of the orchestra more generally, creating coherent and original sounds to fit each piece. Ellington’s mastery of the individual players’ sound, as well as how they fit together in a growing ensemble, enabled him to write some of the most innovative and brilliant pieces in jazz history.
The Grove Music dictionary, in discussing Ellington’s sound and innovation, mentions Creole Love Call in reference to using voice “as a jazz instrument” throughout his career.  This is an early example of Ellington’s use of voice to add texture and color without the hindrance of lyrics. Creole Love Call also demonstrates Ellington’s ability to compliment the style of his soloists, something that is evident throughout his career. This slow, deliberate twelve bar blues piece contains six choruses, as follows:
Chorus 1: Call and response between voice and reeds, where the voice begins smooth and melodic, then transitions to a rougher sound towards the end.
Chorus 2: Muted trumpet solo that elaborates on the basic melody and emphasizes several extended blue notes.
Chorus 3: Sweeping clarinet solo in a high register, backed by a subtle syncopated piano phrase.
Chorus 4: Full band echoes the first chorus with a call and response by the brass and reed sections.
Chorus 5: The climactic chorus of the piece, as the reeds now begin the call and response in a high register, backed by syncopated stop time from the brass and rhythm sections.
Chorus 6: A return to the structure of the first chorus, with call and response between voice and reeds. In this chorus the voice takes on the sound of the “growl” technique, soloing as an instrument.
Tag: Brief tag featuring a vocal run and a dissonant novelty ending by a trombone.
Ellington’s use of voice to add a dimension of tone color to this piece is one example of a stylistic trait that permeates his work. 
In Hot and Bothered, recorded a year later, Ellington combines his skill at tight orchestration with his ear for tone color. A call and response phrase between “Bubber” Miley on muted trumpet and Baby Cox’s scat singing uses the vocal elements of Miley’s playing and instrumental aspects of Cox’s voice to create a rich and complementary sound. It Don’t Mean a Thing (If It Ain’t Got That Swing) extends these ideas, as Ellington uses Joe “Tricky Sam” Nanton, a mainstay in Ellington’s orchestra, to great effect in introducing the melody on muted trombone.

Why do organisms evolve in the manner that they do‭? ‬Are there restrictions or constraints that influence the direction of evolutionary change‭? ‬Although in‭ ‬1917‭ ‬D’Arcy Thompson stated that‭ “‬Even now the zoologist has scarce begun to dream of defining in mathematical language even the simplest organic forms‭” ‬the same can be said today. More recently,‭ ‬mathematical modeling has been applied to general aspects of mollusk skeletogenesis through both ontogeny and phylogeny‭ (‬e.g.,‭ ‬Raup and Stanley,‭ ‬1981‭)‬. Our study is exploring how mathematical modeling of ontogenetic and phylogenetic change in Prunum,‭ ‬in combination with experimental studies,‭ ‬can be used to elucidate the mechanisms involved in the direction and magnitude of evolutionary-developmental change. We used X-radiographic images of Prunum species to delineate quantitative parameters that could in turn be used to model hypothetical and actual skeletal morphologies. These parameters were entered into the software program CerioShell‭ (‬Stone,‭ ‬1995‭)‬. We modeled hypothetical shell morphologies that could be used to interpret the boundaries of possible morphological change in Prunum. These results are being combined with experimental and descriptive studies in order to better understand macroevolutionary events in this clade.

A shell can be thought of as a structure that is a tube that travels over time through‭ ‬360‭ ‬degrees of space.  These revolutions or turns of a coiled shell are called whorls,‭ ‬which are considered to spiral around an imaginary central axis.  This axis runs through the central column of the shell and is known as the columella. The speed at which the whorls enlarge can vary,‭ ‬and a continuous line separates each whorl and is referred to as a suture.  In most shells,‭ ‬the largest whorl of a shell is the last whorl‭ (‬body whorl‭)‬.  ‭ ‬The spire is considered to be all the whorls except the last. The apex is the tip of the spire and the opposite end is referred to as the base. The animal extends out of its shell through an opening called the aperture.

Shells can be viewed in apical,‭ ‬basal,‭ ‬apertural and abapertural views. ‭(‬The‭ "‬usual‭" ‬orientation of a shell is an apertural view,‭ ‬with the aperture toward the viewer and with the apex pointing up.‭)‬

A method for counting whorls is seen below.  First,‭ ‬the shell should be viewed from the apical view and then it should be determined where the first suture begins.  A line can be then drawn dividing the shell into two parts.  Whorls are counted from this line,‭ ‬and are estimated to a quarter of a whorl.

A shell can be viewed as a series of apertures that travel through time and space as the animal accretes‭ (‬i.e. builds‭) ‬its shell.  It is possible to trace the path of the aperture via coordinates of the center of each whorl’s aperture as well as the horizontal and vertical radius of the aperture.

This trajectory can be graphically and mathematically represented.  Once a mathematical formulation is made,‭ ‬it is then possible to vary parameters and modify the mollusk’s skeletogenesis.

The rate of neonatal and infant mortality in Indonesia remained rather static for the last ten years.  While the country is on track to meet many of the Millennium Development Goals, such as the water and sanitation targets, the rates of improvement for child and maternal health are woefully short of the improvements needed to meet their target goals by 2015.  The multiple reasons for these shortcomings will be discussed below, and point to a need to strengthen the health system rather than focus on programmatic interventions.
	Indonesia has made improvements in the number of births with a skilled health worker attending, with 72% of births now meeting this target.  That being said, this category still includes traditional workers, such as midwives, who cannot provide medical interventions should the pregnancy be complicated (hence the large percentage of maternal deaths caused by hemorrhage).  In other words,  the improvements made in this particular indicator are somewhat misleading and there is still much work to be done.  In addition, there has been a decline in the percentage of diarrheal cases in children under five years treated by a health professional.  While data on postnatal care is incomplete, it is clear that this area is also of concern, with low rates across the country.
	Cesarian-section rates are still lower than should be expected, around 4%.  The c-section rates additionally point to another concerning issue.  While the rate of c-section is 7% in urban settings, it is only 2% in rural.  This points to the problem of equity of coverage across the country.  Clearly access to healthcare services is focused around urban areas.  Another issue of access concerns vertical equity.  There is a 27% gap in service utilization between the poorest and richest quintiles.  Clearly the poor are finding it much more difficult to access healthcare services, likely due to out of pocket costs.
	In discussing next steps towards improving neonatal and maternal care indicators, the most basic question is how to most effectively address the lack of service.  Specifically, should Indonesia develop program-specific approaches or strengthen the overall health system without focusing on pre and post-pregnancy care for the mother and child.  There is no question that programmatic approaches to solve the problems outlined above are attractive.  Not only do “vertical approaches” that target one sector of improvements have much more targeted, manageable objectives, they also generally generate faster results.  There are some drawbacks to keep in mind, however.  One major drawback is that investing heavily in programming for one particular area of the health sector often means that funding for other areas suffers and human resources will flock towards working in that area that has more resources (the effect of international funding to HIV/AIDS and its effect on the family planning sector is one example).  In addition, running multiple parallel programs for one area results in duplication of services that are also uncoordinated between programs.  This leads to an increase in forms and paperwork for supplies and funding.

‎	‏The classification of Popular Music has grown over the past‭ ‬100‭ ‬years to include so many genres that it is difficult to definitively list them all. Complicating matters,‭ ‬most if not all genres—rap,‭ ‬rock,‭ ‬country,‭ ‬jazz,‭ ‬folk,‭ ‬just to name a few—have spawned multiple sub and sub-sub genres within their domain.  Arguably the sub-genre of Heavy Metal rock has become one of the most diverse and expressive genres of all popular music in the past‭ ‬40‭ ‬years. It is expressive because it displays a wide range of emotions,‭ ‬although they tend to lean toward the darker side of the spectrum. It is diverse in that quite soon after the beginnings of the genre,‭ ‬people started to realize that it had real flexibility and started to take advantage of it to create their own sub-genre,‭ ‬which then was followed by sub-sub-genres,‭ ‬and the chain continues until today. 

Today we have reached a point in the heavy metal movement where there are so many niches of groups that it is hard to determine what exactly heavy metal is. It has grown to incorporate so many themes from other genres,‭ ‬but like everything else,‭ ‬it spawned from somewhere. In order to properly understand the metal music that exists everywhere today,‭ ‬one must first understand what the metal movement is,‭ ‬and why it’s a movement rather than just a genre.

‎	‏Metal is,‭ ‬in many ways,‭ ‬a movement defined by darkness. Metal can be considered a‭ “‬music of more‭”—‬more bass,‭ ‬more volume,‭ ‬more violence,‭ ‬more theatricality. Less primitivism,‭ ‬more chops‭; ‬people in metal bands really know how to play their instrument,‭ ‬and it comes through in the music. Metal is also—although it may not come as a surprise—a movement that is heavily drug induced. There was a psychedelic drug boom in the mid-70‭’‬s that led to people getting crazier,‭ ‬leading to them to make crazy,‭ ‬other-worldly records,‭ ‬using the drugs as a scapegoat for their creation. It possesses many dark,‭ ‬visceral qualities,‭ ‬which was very new to the music scene because a large amount of popular music had qualities that weren’t true to the darker side of the emotional spectrum. Also,‭ ‬later generations of metal have taken some of their influence from the dark,‭ ‬visceral qualities that were so present in the Romantic Era. Lyrics such as the following express the darkness that is such a staple of the movement:‭ (‬Byrne‭)‬


	
These lyrics from Helter Skelter display the darker side of the Beatles. It exhibits an up and down,‭ ‬supposedly that of drugs. This song is considered by some to be one of the first Heavy Metal songs. It was a response to a Rolling Stones song that was also on the heavier,‭ ‬darker side. The Beatles wanted to prove that they could be just as heavy as the Stones,‭ ‬so they put that song on‭ ‬The White Album.

A few decades before the Surrealist artists began painting their dreamlike works, the artist Henri Rousseau was carefully crafting his own dreams, literally and figuratively. The Dream, a 1910 painting by the famous Post-Impressionist artist, represents not only a woman in awe at the wonders of the land she visits within a dream, but also Rousseau’s own personal dreams and goals as a painter. Since beginning his work, he dreamed of recognition, acceptance, and praise by other artists and art lovers, and found that he was faced with a difficult internal dilemma to achieve this aspiration. The Dream is Henri Rousseau’s work that best reflects his career-long internal struggle: to either conform to or mimic certain styles of painting in order to be accepted by the critical art world he so adored, or to allow himself to be creatively independent and unique, leaving his own path as he went.
Before one can analyze The Dream through this perspective, one must first be somewhat familiar with Rousseau’s biographical story. Henri Rousseau was born on May 21, 1844, in the town of Laval in northwest France. His father was a tinsmith and hardware dealer who “enjoyed bourgeois prosperity” (Shattuck 47). Growing up, he received no formal training in the arts; instead, he was employed until the age of forty working for France as a gabelou, or employee of the municipal toll service, although he received the misnomer sobriquet of douanier, a customs inspector (Shattuck 46). The death of his first wife, Clémence, which followed the deaths of eight infant children, left Rousseau with only one child, a daughter named Julia, and immense grief (Shattuck 49). He therefore hoped to take refuge in a new life and pursued painting to offer him comfort and fresh beginnings. Unlike contemporary colleagues of Rousseau who sentimentalize and romanticize the peasant in painting, he is essentially a folk painter and has the hopes and dreams of the average member of his class.
Rousseau’s obsession with being accepted by the art world is somewhat understandable when evaluated in context: as discussed, he was not only uneducated in the ways of formal painting and began his career at a much older age, but he was producing works at the same time as many other talented and better-known modern artists. Though working for many years already, Rousseau did not begin to receive proper recognition for his art until around the same time that Matisse had begun crafting a reputation as an artist. In the book Modern French Painters, author Jan Gordon asserts that the two, while technically competitors in the art arena, were different not only in style and subject matter but also their reasons for painting in the first place: “Matisse was a painter who conceived a terror of painting in a trite way, while Rousseau’s desire was to paint a picture so conventional that he would be admitted to the Artiste Français” (92).

Many a great thinker has postulated an intimate connection between ethics and aesthetics, between truth and beauty. I believe that at a fundamental level there is a reason for this. As John Keats says in “Ode on a Grecian Urn”, “Beauty is truth, truth beauty- That is all / Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know.” Much of what we know in life is learned via education or experience. However, we seem to appreciate ethics and aesthetics, as Keats implies, without being taught in these expected ways. Both ethics and aesthetics are an attempt to describe rather then prescribe. Our studies of morality and beauty are, for the most part, attempts to explain why a piece of art or literature is beautiful, or why an action is moral, rather than a set of rules for judging, or creating, good art or moral behavior. 
	More to the point, criticism of art or morals is never able to fully capture the essence of what is good or what is beautiful. A conversation about the worth of da Vinci's Mona Lisa, for example, may center around concepts like foreground, background, contrast, or cultural context, but in the end, these do not describe why it is good art. Rather, when one is asked about a favorite work of art or literature it is common to hear a phrase similar to, “There's just something about it” preceding a more complex or critical explanation. I believe that both art and morals can never be completely reduced to a description of their qualities. As Flannery O'Connor says, “A story is a way to say something that can't be said any other way . . . you tell a story because a statement would be inadequate.” No matter how completely we describe the properties of a work of literature, there is something transcendent which is still left. I believe that ethics has this same property. As Wittgenstein says, “It is clear that ethics cannot be expressed. / Ethics is transcendental. / . I suggest that it is this “something”, this je ne sais quoi, which is art and morality's most powerful attribute, and that this transcendental nature of both ethics and aesthetics provides a connection point between them.
	I believe that morality and art are so closely related because we experience both of them most powerfully at a noumenally, to use a Kantian term. They impact us at a level that can be experienced, but not fully explained. This link is even stronger when it comes to the art of literature. As McKean says, “What most distinguishes literature from the other arts, what is, in truth, unique about the art, is its moral quality. It may be that moral standards are inappropriate to other arts, music, for instance, but they seem to be as relevant to literature as they are to life itself. Living necessarily involves values. . . . Literature is important to us precisely because of the values we find there” .

The Germany of today is considered a strong force, a united country with its own blend of culture from within the shadows of the alps in München, all the way to Baltic sea city of Kiel.  The same culture can be felt from Köln on the river Rhine, through the centre of Germany to the Saxon city of Dresden located on the Elbe. With such a unique culture, it shouldn't be surprising that Germany as we now know it comes from several different sources, and tribes. 

Germania is the ancestral land of the Germans. The origins of the name are highly disputed among scholars and historians. Tacitus claimed that the name came from a Germanic Tribe known then as Tungrians, and that they had previously been known as Germans before they crossed the Rhine and battled the Gaulish forces (Tacitus, 98.) Julius Caesar first used the word “Germanus” in his commentary on the Gallic Wars where he put down the Gauls and battled with Germanic tribes which crossed the Rhine often under mischievous premisses. He took this word from The Gauls themselves, and used it to distinguish between those which he had conquered (The Gauls) and those which he had not. While the origin is uncertain, some believe it referred to a neighbor in the Gaulish language. In the first chapter, of his first book on these wars, Julius Caesar notes: “Germans, who dwell beyond the Rhine, with whom they (The Gauls) are continually waging war.....They contend with the Germans in almost daily battles.” (Julius Caesar, 50-40 BC) Others claim the meaning comes from the spear that they used in warfare, known as a ger (O.E.D, 2010), or perhaps from the Old Irish word garim meaning “to shout”, which indicated the Germans were loud, or noisy. (Names of Germany) 

 The early Roman historian Tacitus recorded in his AD 98 writing “De Origine et situ Germanorum”, which told of the origins of the Germans, that “I should regard (The Germans) as aboriginal, and not mixed at all with other races through immigration or intercourse. For, in former times it was not by land but on shipboard that those who sought to emigrate would arrive.......Who would leave Asia, or Africa, for Italy for Germany, with its wild country, its inclement skies, its sullen manners and aspect, unless indeed it were his home?(SIC)” (Tacitus, 98) 

And who would leave Rome for Germania? Certainly not the Romans, not yet at least. They would send out their conquests into the lands of Germania for goods, and lead the occasional land campaign but in the end they mostly returned back home to their sprawling empire. So as the Germanic tribes began appearing in the middle of the first century, they lived on the borders of the Roman Empire and traded their goods taken from the land, and their skills by serving within the ranks of the Roman army, (Ozment, 2005 pg. 17.)

The play Twelfth Night seems to say that although disguise is in fact useful in perpetrating long bouts of deception, in the end a person must reject that newly formed guise, or else risk losing themselves forever in the process. A big problem with ending a deception, however, is that one may find themselves alienated in the process. Therefore, in the end, one must decide between one’s own self preservation, or the preservation of relationships with those around them. For although some will respond neutrally to discovering that they’ve been tricked, still others will not take the deception so lightly, and will be likely be offended by the whole charade.
The topic of deception in gender role reversal is especially problematic, because it brings up many side issues, perhaps the most important one being, why? Why does the subject feel the need to shirk their own identity and take up a disguise in the form of the opposite gender? In Viola’s case, it is obviously a form of self protection.: “I’ll bring you to a captain in this town/ Where lie my maiden weeds, by whose gentle help/ I was preserved to serve this noble count…” (5.1.247-249)
Having newly arrived in a foreign land, Viola feels it necessary to pretend to be a man to protect herself from would be attackers. Viola’s plan works, but it also alienates her from the women around her, cutting her off from an important support system. To make matters worse, she is apparently so convincing at appearing to be a man that Olivia confuses her with Sebastian, and in effect falls in love with her. “Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay.” (5.1.138) On top of that, she also has to deal with suppressed romantic desires between her and Orsino: “Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times/ Thou never shouldst love woman like to me.” (5.1. 260-261)
Although this may be a somewhat progressive attitude, to the modern reader, Twelfth Night may be seen as an illustration of how deception may help facilitate the unveiling of suppressed emotions, especially in the cases of Olivia and Orsino. Certain passages seem to hint that the aforesaid characters may have unexpressed subconscious desires that the appearance of Viola/Cesario forces them to deal with. For instance, is Olivia attracted to Cesario because Cesario appears to be a man, or does Olivia really secretly harbor feelings for women? One would argue that this is probably not the case, because Shakespeare’s character Olivia seems more likely to be parodying those people of his time period who judge others only upon their looks. 
This is evidenced by the ease with which Olivia switches her romantic ardors from Cesario to Sebastian, and begins to regard Cesario/Viola as family rather than a love interest: “A sister, you are she.” (5.1.315)

German colonial rule has been noted by various observers for its brutality, notably with respect to the genocide of the Ovaherero and Nama in German South West Africa. Of course nothing so broad as an entire colonial empire can be accounted for by such a simple description. The German colonial empire was as varied in policies and ruling style as it was in geography. Educational provision across the colonies was similarly diverse. When the British took over German East Africa (Tanganyika) in 1919, they found a large population of educated and literate Africans. German educational efforts in Kamerun and other colonies were also praised by contemporary authors. 
The situation in South West Africa (present-day Namibia) presented a stark contrast.  Unlike in East Africa, where the government established state schools and played a prominent role in the education of the natives, in South West Africa the task of native education was left almost entirely to missionary societies that received limited government support. The government did however invest significant resources towards the education of Europeans in the colony, establishing s system of state schools as well as more heavily supporting and regulating missionary schools. These educational policies had longstanding effects on South West Africa, even after German rule. While other German colonies boasted significant numbers of literate and educated Africans, in South West Africa “the overwhelming majority of the population remained untouched, uneducated, and illiterate.” Various social, political, and economic factors led to the divergent experience of South West Africa. This paper seeks to expand the discussion by identifying these factors and paying particular attention to new research on the attitudes of settlers and colonial authorities to native Africans.
There is a wealth of literature dealing with education in the German colonial empire specifically. Most of these sources are in German and were written in the early twentieth century, during or shortly after the period of German colonial rule. The aim of early works was primarily to describe the features of educational systems in these colonies. Later writings in English expanded the discourse through comparative studies of education in the various German colonies and more detailed analyses of specific aspects of education. These studies illustrated significant differences in the educational systems of different colonies. The most prominent work to explicitly address the topic of this paper is Cohen’s study of education in South West Africa and East Africa. Cohen compares the educational systems of the two colonies and discusses the factors that account for the differences between them. According to Cohen, the large settler population of South West Africa explains many of the distinguishing aspects of the colony’s educational system.
Compared to Germany’s other colonial possessions, South West Africa had a moderately temperate climate, although much of the territory is covered by arid desert. The European population of South West Africa reflected the relatively hospitable conditions. By 1913 nearly 15,000 whites lived in South West Africa, while only 5,336 lived in the colony with the next largest settler population, East Africa.

The United States of America and Mexico are an example of two nations which at one time were beset by an enduring rivalry which spanned 57 years, from 1836 to 1893. (Diehl and Goerts 2000 p. 145).  The high-water mark of this rivalry was the Mexican-American War of 1846-1848, where the United States attacked and defeated Mexico and secured for itself Texas and the American Southwest as new territory.  Many other clashes happened between the two nations, finally abating just before the First World War.   The rivalry began as Americans and Mexicans clashed on key issues such as religion, culture and tradition and had a major clash of material interests (Schmitt 1974 p. 30-31).   
	This is not unlike many other nations who have an enduring rivalry with a neighbor.  Nations which share a border tend to have clashes of interests which lend to the creation of rival positions between the nations.  The United States and Mexico are not unlike many other enduring rivalries between nations which share a common border.  David M. Pletcher (1977) states that “Only in Mexico and Cuba can one find long-lasting overarching American diplomatic problems” (p. 41).  Indeed, both of these nations are geographically close to the United States and have been rivals to the United States, while other nations in Latin America enjoy and have enjoyed good relations with the United States.   
	Religious issues created a rift between the two nations, a problem which has beset many nations through history.  Sally Frahm (2001) states that ”if in the twentieth century Americans were opposed to fascism and communism, in the eighteenth and nineteenth they were opposed to Catholicism and monarchy”  (p.86).  Not unlike the Cold War’s rivalry between the United States and the Soviet Union was part ideological struggle and part a competition over interests each nation deemed vital. In this case, however, the ideological struggles weren’t based on the political structure but on instead the religious preferences of the United States and Mexico.  This distrust grew from the distrust between the English and Spanish.  Inheriting these feelings of distrust from their former colonial rulers was a major obstacle in the establishment of amiable foreign relations between the United States and Mexico.
	Diehl and Goerts (2000) list 17 disputes between Mexico and the United States in the 57-year rivalry period.   The majority of disputes between the rivalry period described by Diehl and Goerts are territorial issues relating to border raids from Mexican territory into Mexico and other frontier problems.  Border raids by bandits and outlaws from on American border towns were a major problem which remained until both the United States and Mexico exerted military force on their borders (Schmitt 1974 p. 97).  
Schmitt (1974) explains the rivalry between the two nation began to abate as “Mexico became clearly dependent on the United States in a substantial way” (p. 109) and finally ended as American ambitions “changed from territorial expansion to economic intervention into Mexico” (p.110) in the later part of the 19th Century.

Fifteen‭ ‬years ago I became suddenly and unexpectedly disabled by an illness I never knew existed. 

 I was a nurse at the time. I had chosen my profession out of a deeply entrenched need for the safety and security I didn't have as a child. ‭"‬You'll always be able to find work‭; ‬people will always get sick.‭" ‬was the mantra I heard over and over as I reached adolescence and beyond. So--‭ ‬even though my dream was to be a scientist or a journalist-preferably a little of both,‭ ‬I chose nursing. 

Nevertheless,‭ ‬there I was:‭ ‬46‭ ‬years old and single,‭ ‬no money in the bank to speak of and unable to work. To this day I am disabled,‭ ‬and after‭ ‬15‭ ‬years of living on Social Security Disability,‭ ‬I have literally nothing left that I can call‭ "‬mine.‭" ‬I get by,‭ ‬but every day is a struggle and an assault on my security,‭ ‬safety and self-esteem. Nothing in my life is certain anymore,‭ ‬yet,‭ ‬there is one thing that I know to be true. I could not have gotten by for all these years were it not for the help of my family and a few good friends,‭ ‬no matter how strong I was. And believe me,‭ ‬when real disaster strikes,‭ ‬you do not feel very strong at all. 

My point is that there will always be emergencies in life-big and small.  There are no guarantees and no matter how well one prepares,‭ ‬some things are just too big to overcome on your own. 

I agree wholeheartedly that we in the U.S. need to stop putting all of our eggs in big government's‭ "‬basket‭"; ‬Lord knows it is moldy‭ ‬and falling apart,‭ ‬anyway. Yet I would much rather see Americans learning to trust one another again‭–‬learning to help each other and to ask for help,‭ ‬rather‭ ‬than have each of us individually clambering out to the backyard to build fallout shelters. 

The Conservatives in the US talk about the‭ "‬rugged individualism‭" ‬that built this country‭; ‬but in truth,‭ ‬what kept our forefathers going in hard times wasn't rugged individualism,‭ ‬it was compassion,‭ ‬mutual respect and the sharing of resources. The pioneers who crossed the Rockies in wagon trains didn't make it to the coast by going it alone. 


So,‭ ‬by all means,‭ ‬be prepared. I am. I have a disaster kit‭; ‬first‭ ‬aid supplies,‭ ‬water purifying tablets and plastic sheeting and duct tape for the windows in the event of a biological attack. I have several flashlights and all sorts of batteries,‭ ‬lots and lots of candles and waterproof matches and canned goods,‭ ‬too. If‭ ‬you have the land and the resources for a small farm and the ability to can or preserve your own food-do it. It's a great idea,‭ ‬as is a wood stove,‭ ‬as long as you do not live in an apartment. 

But while you are at it,‭ ‬get to know your neighbors.

Sometime in the fifth or sixth century BCE, a prince who would one day be called Buddha was born. Over the course of his life, he renounced the world and became enlightened, and his teachings led to the formation of Buddhism—the most orthodox sect of which is known as Theravada Buddhism. The religion is around twenty five hundred years old; it looks different today than it did when Buddha was alive. This can be seen all over, for instance in the Theravada nation of Sri Lanka, where the annual water-cutting ceremony is observed. Monks and laymen alike participate in this ceremony, and it holds some religious significance, despite Buddha never teaching about any festivity of the sort. These differences run all the way from the superficial traditions to the soteriological core of the religion. The Theravada Buddhist community, both from the monastic perspective and from the lay perspective, has had to change its doctrinal principles over time. This can be attributed to forces both external and internal, both hostile and benign.
	There are a number of qualifying terms this discussion will make frequent use of. There is the concept of internal versus external. Here, an internal force is defined as a force borne of members of the Buddhasasana, regardless of monastic status. An external force is any force from non-Buddhists. A hostile force is any force that damages or intends to damage the Buddhist community—a force borne of a negative perception of Buddhism. A benign force is a force that does not wish to harm or help the Buddhist community—though it may end up doing one or the other as a byproduct. These terms will come up repeatedly throughout this discussion.
	First, it is important to investigate the basics of the religion—the doctrines that lie at the core of Theravada Buddhism. Buddhists seek refuge in the triple gem of the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha. The Dhamma is essentially comprised of the Tripitaka—the three baskets—of Buddhist text. The Sutta Pitaka contains all the Suttas, the Vinaya Pitaka contains the disciplinary rules, and the Abhidhamma Pitaka contains the metaphysical components of Buddhism. The metaphysical notions consist of things like Anatta—no soul, Dukkha—inherent suffering in life, and Anicca—impermanence of everything. Only by recognizing these concepts can one end Sansara, the cycle of death and rebirth, which happens continuously. Along with Sansara will end lobha—desire, dosa—hatred, and moha—delusion, when one becomes enlightened. In the Vinaya Pitaka, rules for life are set forth. For laymen, there are five precepts (I shall not kill, I shall not lie, I shall not steal, I shall not misbehave sexually, and I shall not take intoxicating substances). For monks, there are many more disciplinary rules to be followed. The most fundamental doctrinal notion in Buddhism is the notion of the four noble truths. First, Dukkha; the truth that life is suffering. Second, that attachment causes suffering. Third, that suffering can be overcome.
transformed_texts:
He sat there thinking about culture and what it meant in the dealings of men. Not a thing you could hold in your hand nor touch with your fingers but there all the same. Like wind. Like God maybe. He'd seen it in the way men moved and talked and in their eyes when they looked at you across a table where papers lay waiting to be signed. Papers that meant something to someone somewhere.

The old man had told him once that you couldn't say what a people were like in just a word or two. Couldn't say the Russians were this way or the Japanese were that way. The old man knew. He'd been there in places where the language was strange and the customs stranger still but he knew that men were men wherever you found them.

When you went into another man's country you carried your own country with you whether you meant to or not. Like a shadow that wouldn't leave. You saw things through eyes that had been shaped by your own place and time and there wasn't any helping it.

In the corporate towers they had their own ways too. Like tribes maybe. Some wore suits that cost more than a working man's monthly wage and some came to work in denims and tshirts. Some wanted you there before the sun came up and some didn't care when you showed up long as the work got done. Each place had its own rules written and unwritten and if you didn't know them you'd find out soon enough.

He thought about values and what they meant. In some places a man's word was everything and in others it wasn't worth the air it took to speak it. Some cultures valued harmony above all else and would rather lose face than cause discord. Others saw negotiation like war and wouldn't yield an inch without bleeding for it first.

The key was knowing your man. Not just his culture or his company's ways but knowing him as a man. What he wanted. What he feared. What he'd fight for and what he'd let go. Without that you were just guessing and guessing could get you killed at the negotiating table just as sure as it could in the desert or the mountains where men fought with bullets instead of words.

The fool speaks of godlessness in his heart and darkness follows. Found first in the old psalms and later in Anselm's writings, these words echo through time like footfalls in an empty church. Aquinas too walked these shadowed halls of thought, both men seeking proof of what cannot be touched.

To speak of their arguments we must accept their God as real and true, the God of scripture and stone tablets, not some nebulous force moving through the void. Their God had a son. Their God had wrath. Their God spoke through burning bushes and parted seas.

Anselm's path leads inward, deep into the chambers of the mind where understanding dwells like a flame in darkness. He would say God exists because we know it in our bones, in the marrow of our thoughts. That you cannot truly imagine His absence any more than you can imagine the absence of truth itself. Faith lives here, in these inner rooms where reason fears to tread.

But Aquinas walked a different road. He gathered evidence like a man gathering firewood, piece by piece, building his case with cold logic and colder reason. Five proofs he laid out like stones in a path: change, cause, necessity, perfection, and order. Each one leading to God like tracks in the sand lead to the sea. He would say you need no faith when the truth stands before you plain as day. That God can be proven like theorems are proven, with hard facts and harder logic.

Yet neither man's path leads all the way home. They are like blind men touching different parts of the same vast beast, each describing only what their hands can reach. One feels the trunk, the other the tusk, but neither sees the whole. The truth of God, if there be such a truth, lies somewhere beyond both faith and reason, in that twilight realm where both paths end and something else begins.

Words lay like dead things on the page and the way a writer might string them together to make meaning was a thing beyond knowing. But Fitzgerald he knew something of this and in his book about the man Gatsby he worked at it like a craftsman might work metal or wood, bending and shaping until the thing took form. He used words in ways they weren't meant to be used, pairing them wrong like mismatched horses in a team, but somehow they pulled true. And he took colors and made them mean things they had no business meaning, gold and green and white and gray and red, all of them carrying weight like pack animals bearing loads too heavy for their frames.

The white and gray they spoke of sameness, of things worn smooth by time and use. White being the color of money and privilege, gray being what white becomes when hope dies. You could see it in how he wrote it. Everywhere white clothes like banners of surrender. Daisy and Jordan floating in white like ghosts. Nick in his white flannels and Tom in his white shirt and Catherine powdered white as bone. Only at Gatsby's did the colors rage wild and primary like something torn loose from its moorings. The rest was all white chasms in the city and gray names written in gray books and white buildings lined up like headstones. A white girlhood that might never have happened at all. Gray cars and gray land in that valley where ashes fell like snow that never melted.

He used these colors like a man might use a knife, cutting meaning into things. When Daisy came back she was all in white, driving a white car, and you could see then what she was - just another piece in a game being played out. Not a woman at all but a thing to be possessed, wrapped in gray fur like something already dead. She moved through the story like a sleepwalker, all in white, never touching the ground, never leaving footprints. Just another ghost in Gatsby's haunted house.

The county lay before them like some vast promise, the mild air carrying whispers of citrus and tomato vines stretching endless toward the horizon. Fields there were, and orchards, the fruit hanging heavy and low, peaches and lemons both, and berries dark as blood in the morning sun. Men and women worked these fields without the poisons of their fathers, their hands calloused testaments to labors ancient and true. The waiting lists for such pure food grew long as scripture, the people hungry for eggs still warm from their laying, milk white as God's own blessing.

They came to walk these lands, these pilgrims, to witness the workings of soil and seed. To watch birds wheel overhead in formations old as time. The government men came too with their papers and promises, speaking of programs and benefits, but the land cared nothing for such things. It gave forth its bounty or it did not.

The price was steep. Without the chemicals that had scoured the earth in years past, the work grew harder. Weeds pushed through like memories of Eden, insects came in biblical swarms. The small farmers watched their larger brothers with their machines and their poisons, knowing they could never match such efficiency. Yet they persisted. They planted cover crops in the wisdom of their grandfathers, moved their cattle in patterns like old ceremonies, fought back the invasive species that came like thieves in the night.

Near Potrero they found land. One hundred and sixty acres where chaparral met grassland, where oak trees stood sentinel as dark prophets. The Cleveland Forest pressed against it like a ancient wall. Here the creatures dwelt that man had nearly destroyed - the kangaroo rat, the yellow-legged frog, butterflies nameless and rare as answered prayers. The burrowing owl watched from its underground cathedral, its future uncertain as all futures must be.

Before the ranchers came with their cattle and their axes, before they felled the trees for cordwood, the Indians had walked these hills. Their ghosts still moved through the oak shadows, their footsteps quiet as falling leaves. The homesteaders came after, their patent on the land a piece of paper that meant everything and nothing. They grazed their cattle and cut their wood and were in turn forgotten.

He studied the property listings like a man reading auguries, searching for signs in the government programs that might make such a venture possible. Somewhere nearby another farm had found this balance, this covenant between profit and preservation. He thought perhaps he could do the same, though the path was dark and the outcome uncertain as all things must be in this world.

Brothers carry bonds that run deeper than blood. Deep as stone. Deep as time itself. They look upon each other and see not just flesh and bone but mirrors of themselves, reflections cast back through the dark waters of time. In these waters swim love and pride and cruelty and things without names, ancient things that have no words in any tongue of man.

The boy called Doodle came into this world broke and bent, his heart weak as a sparrow's. His brother watched him, studied him like some strange creature pulled from the depths, wondering if he'd draw breath come morning. Some nights he'd stand over the cradle thinking dark thoughts, his small hands hovering above the pillow like pale spiders. But then Doodle smiled and something in his brother's heart cracked open like an egg.

Pride's a terrible thing. It burns in the blood like poison. The brother had dreamed of someone to race through the pinewoods, to climb the old vines that hung like gallows rope in Woman Swamp, to swim the black waters of Horsehead Landing. But Doodle could barely crawl. Could barely stand. His legs thin as twigs, his chest rising and falling with each labored breath.

They moved through that green country like pilgrims in some ancient fable. The brother leading, Doodle following, their footprints marking the red clay like stigmata. Above them the pines stood sentinel, their branches reaching toward a sky gone gray as gunmetal. The ibis came later, red as blood, red as sin, falling from that same sky like some divine omen. But by then it was too late. Pride had done its work. The storm had come. And in its wake only one brother remained to tell the tale.

The mind of man aint nothing simple. It works in ways we cannot know and cannot tell. Time was when men thought it no more than marks pressed into wax or words scratched onto dried reeds from the river. Then they said it was like them books that gathered dust in libraries. Now they say its like them machines that hum and click and speak in numbers. But all these things is just words and words aint truth.

The way the mind takes in the world is like this. Light falls on the eye and sound moves through the air and the flesh feels what it touches and all these things become something else. Something that aint quite real no more but aint quite dream neither. The mind takes these things and works em over. Sometimes it works from the bottom up like when you're looking at something you aint never seen before. Other times it works from what it already knows, like when you seen something before and your mind already knows what its fixing to see. Like looking at a black square drawn on white paper. Your eyes see the edges first, where black meets white, but your mind already knows what its gonna be before your eyes is done looking.

The mind decides what's worth paying mind to and what aint. Like how you can walk across grass and never see each blade even though your eyes take em all in, or how you can hear your name called out in a crowd even when theres a hundred other voices speaking. The mind sifts through it all like a prospector panning for gold.

Everything that goes into the mind has got to be stored somewhere. There's different kinds of storing, like how you can remember something just happened or something from long ago. First the mind has to take it in, like how words can be remembered for how they look wrote down or how they sound spoke or what they mean in the deep dark of your thoughts. Some men who study animals say the quick memories that last about twenty seconds is like electricity running round and round through the brain, while the old memories is stored in the very meat of the mind itself, in them little bits they call proteins.

They got different ways of thinking bout how all this knowledge is put together in there. Some say its like a web where everything's connected to everything else that's like it. Like how chair connects to table connects to wood and on and on until everything in the world is tied together in ways we cant see but the mind knows. But that's just another story we tell ourselves in the dark.

They called it a crisis but it was more like a slow death. The kind that creeps up on you in the night when you're sleeping warm in your bed dreaming of better days. In 2007 the country fell. Not with cannon fire or trumpet blast but with the quiet clicking of computers and the rustling of papers in tall glass buildings where men in suits watched numbers fall like dead leaves in autumn.

The streets grew empty. Houses stood like tombstones with their windows dark and their doors locked against owners who would never return. Men who once wore suits now carried cardboard signs at intersections. Their eyes vacant. Their hands trembling. Everything that was solid turned to ash.

It started in the time of Clinton. A president who wanted more years in his white house like a king who cant let go his crown. He loosened the chains that held the banks in check. Let them run wild and free like rabid dogs through the streets of commerce. A man named Holmes wrote about it in the paper. Saw it coming like a man can see storm clouds gathering on a distant horizon. But no one listened. No one ever listens until the rain starts falling.

They made new kinds of money. Paper promises wrapped in more paper promises. Adjustable rates that adjusted only upward like a hangmans noose drawing ever tighter. CDOs they called them. Complex names for simple greed. The banks grew fat on these paper promises. Built towers of glass and steel that reached toward heaven like the tower of Babel. And like Babel they fell.

When it all came apart it came apart fast. Five great houses of money watched their empires crumble. Four point one trillion dollars. Numbers so big they lose all meaning. Like counting grains of sand in the desert. Bear Stearns fell first. Then Merrill Lynch. Lehman Brothers died in the night. Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley survived but were changed. Broken. Transformed into something else entirely. Something lesser.

Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. Names that sound like characters from a childrens story but there was nothing innocent about them. Five trillion in debt. A number that would make God himself weep. The government took them in the end. Like putting down a rabid dog. It had to be done but nobody wanted to watch.

This is how empires fall. Not with a bang but with the quiet scratch of a pen on paper. With the soft whisper of money changing hands in dark rooms. With promises made that can never be kept. This is how the world ends. Not all at once but piece by piece until theres nothing left but dust and memories and the long dark road ahead.

The words lay dead on the page like birds fallen from winter trees. No life in them. No breath. Just black marks that told of things that never were and never would be. The writer knew this truth but could not help herself from piling more words atop the others like a funeral pyre waiting for flame.

She'd been taught the old ways. Show dont tell they'd said. As if words could do anything but tell. As if showing wasnt just another kind of lying. But she wrote on anyway, filling pages with histories that never happened to people who never lived. Telling of marriages and murders and meetings in the night. Two lines of dialogue was all she gave them. Two lines to speak their piece before the darkness took them.

The husband died on page four. Shot through the heart though no one saw it happen. Just words on a page saying he was dead and she was alone and that was that. No time spent watching him move through the world. No chance to know the weight of his presence or the sound of his breath in the dark. Just gone. Like they all go in the end.

The writer knew better. Knew you had to give them more. Had to put meat on them bones. Had to make them real enough to mourn. But knowing dont make the doing any easier. Sometimes the words come fast and desperate like theyre running from something. Sometimes you just want to get it all down before it slips away. Before the darkness comes.

Like that fellow at the gas station. Ex Air Force they said. Two wives. No kids. Liked to fish. Had dreams about owning the place someday. Ate eggs benedict that morning though God knows where he found hollandaise sauce in this world. All of it true maybe. All of it lies probably. But what difference did it make? He was just words on a page. Just another ghost in a world full of ghosts. Just another story that never got told right.

He watched the news come through the glass eye, the morning light harsh and cold in Columbus. First came word of evil done in Ashley, a man called Hostettler who'd taken blade to wife, the darkness in his eyes staring out from the booking photo like some ancient thing dredged up from below. They gave it two minutes. No more. Just enough to tell of multiple wounds and iron bars that waited.

Then came word of the boy Travis Buyers, eighteen summers old and now laid low by gunshot in Sharon Woods. Critical they said. No arrests. SWAT teams moved like black beetles through the streets but found nothing. The story passed quick as wind through dead grass, like so many tales of the darker folk who fell victim in this godless time. White faces lingered longer on the screen, their stories told and retold until they became legend.

News of a bullet hole in the flying machine they called Med-Flight. Twenty-two caliber from a rifle, they said. Money offered for the shooter's name, five thousand dollars to break the silence that held his identity like a tomb.

Weather came next. Rain and thunder promised for the afternoon, temperatures hovering in the eighties like restless ghosts. Brief words meant to keep eyes fixed to the screen, bait for the commercial break.

Then robbery at the UDF on Clime Road. They spoke of the thief's blackness like it was a thing you could touch, described his dark skin and hood as if painting some nightmare creature. Six foot tall and lean as a winter wolf. They dwelt on his color like men obsessed with darkness.

Last came word of Rodriguez, the drug lord from Texas. Three hundred months they gave him, not twenty-five years, as if counting each month might make the sentence heavier. They named him Hispanic though it mattered not at all to the weight of his crimes or the years that waited to swallow him.

Through it all the news anchor sat pristine and distant as a priest, passing judgment on the day's sins while outside the real world turned, uncaring and vast beneath an indifferent sky.

He studied the numbers laid out before him like bones in the sand, each figure telling its own tale of worth and loss in the vast wasteland of the market. ETF, they called it. Exchange traded fund. A thing that moved like a serpent through the exchanges, tracking indices and commodities with the cold precision of a predator. Not unlike the mutual funds of old but leaner, meaner, more adapted to survive in these harsh financial climes.

The boy looked at the figures. What do they mean Papa, he said.

They mean survival son. A way to spread our chances across the wasteland. Like having many arrows instead of one.

The numbers showed the truth of it. Ten holdings making up near sixty-four percent of the whole thing. Each one carrying its own weight like pack animals in a caravan across the desert of uncertainty. UnitedHealth Group. CVS Health Corp. Elevance Health. Their percentages written in blood-red ink against the stark white paper.

He'd done the calculations in the dim light of evening, figures scratched out with a pencil worn nearly to the nub. The portfolio of ten showed higher returns than its parent, six point eleven percent higher, like a child outgrowing its father. The beta lower by point twelve, as if the offspring had learned to move more cautiously through the financial wilderness.

But numbers could lie. He knew this like he knew the sound of his own breathing in the dark. Statistical significance hung over the data like a shroud, demanding to be acknowledged. Standard deviations lined up like sentries, each one guarding its own truth about risk and return.

The market is no country for old men, he thought. It gives no quarter and asks none in return. Each transaction leaving its mark like the fossilized footprints of ancient creatures in stone.

They sat there in the gathering gloom, father and son, studying the figures as if reading an ancient text that might reveal the secrets of survival in this harsh financial world. The boy looked up at him.

Will it protect us, he said.

Yes. If anything can.

But you're not sure.

No. I'm not sure. Nothing is sure anymore.

The numbers stared back at them, cold and unblinking as the eyes of the dead.

The numbers fell off like dead leaves in that third month. Just fell away. You could study that Figure 17 til your eyes went dim and still not know the why of it. Winter came hard to them New England grounds like it always did, cold and merciless, and them bicycle riders and walkers just disappeared into whatever shelter they could find. December it was. End of term with its burdens of papers and grades weighing down on everyone like stones. Maybe that commuter log just got lost in the shuffle of things, like so many papers do.

The holidays came too. Always do. Campus emptied out like a dead town, buildings standing dark and silent against the gray sky. When January dragged itself in, bringing them students and teachers back, weren't many filling out them logs. February was worse. Numbers so low you could count em on one hand. Might be that first fire of excitement just burned itself out, way fires do when there aint nothing left to feed em.

We tried something then. Called it the Carpool Challenge Week. March it was. Like throwing fresh wood on dying embers, trying to bring that flame back. Worked some. Numbers came up, but they was different somehow. Weaker.

Thing about people is they love their cars. Love em like kin. Its in the blood of this country, deep as original sin. We tried to lure em away with prizes. Gift papers for food and coffee and such. Books too. Even them big store chains. But maybe we should've gone bigger. Bicycle maybe. One of them hybrid cars even. Electric one perhaps. Something to make em sit up and take notice.

Them first prizes worked fine at the start. People's eyes would light up at the mention of em. But they was like giving pennies to a man who needed dollars. If we'd have brought out something bigger in December, maybe one of them bicycles, then come January dropped the news about a car - hybrid or electric, don't matter which - well, might've kept em interested. Might've kept em coming back. Instead of watching em drift away like smoke in that winter wind.

I set to watching them old Edison pictures, them trick films from the turn of the century, fifteen of them laid out before me like cards in some devil's game spanning 1895 to 1901. Strange illusions wrought in silver and light, crafted by men who knew the dark art of cutting and splicing celluloid dreams. They was mostly bound by rules old as theatre itself, rules that grew from the ground like weeds through concrete, choking out any notion of something different.

They kept their pictures in boxes made of sets and stages, all shot straight on like God himself was watching from the cheap seats. Camera bolted down like it was afraid to move. Everything far off or middling far, never close enough to see a man's soul in his eyes. One shot was all they got, one shot was all they needed. Except when it wasnt.

The pictures lived in rooms built special for them, rooms with invisible walls facing forward like church pews. Camera didnt follow nothing. It stood there dead still like a hanging judge, watching. This way of doing came down from theatre folk and carnival men who knew about fooling eyes. Characters moved sideways like crabs, never coming forward, never going back. Take that picture Uncle Josh in a Spooky Hotel. Josh and them others, they shuffle side to side like theyre afraid of something in the deep dark behind the lens.

They shot everything from far off, sometimes a little closer but never close enough to count teeth. Never saw nobody's eyes up close in them days. Theatre folk taught them that too, keeping everything in view all at once like God intended. Actors stayed back where they belonged, away from the glass eye watching them.

Most times one shot was all there was, one minute of magic before the light died. Wasnt much story to tell in sixty seconds. Just tricks and switches, people appearing and vanishing like smoke in wind. But them shots wasnt always what they seemed. Take that old picture of Mary Queen of Scots getting her head cut off. Look close enough and youll see where they stitched the death together, like a butcher hiding the seam in meat.

The Gothic tale aint new and it aint old neither. It's both and that's what Ian Watt called it in his book about such things. Some folks praised it and others cursed it and said it was hollow inside like an old dried gourd left too long in the field. But it had power in it. The kind that makes men shiver and think about what's beyond the dark.

The first of these tales came from Horace Walpole who wrote about a castle and things that happened there. He took old things and new things and mixed them together like a man might mix water and whiskey, knowing neither one alone would do what he needed. The story he made was full of old stone and older shadows, full of things from medieval times when men built great towers that reached up toward God like the fingers of dead men reaching through dirt.

In them days the word gothic meant different things to different folk. Some thought it meant barbarians and others thought it meant them pointed arches in old churches where the light comes down in dusty beams like God's own fingers touching earth. Most folk thought it was something dead and gone, like bones bleaching in the sun. But Walpole, he took that dead thing and breathed life into it, made it walk again.

The heart of these tales was something called chivalry. Not the kind where men open doors for women but the old kind, where knights rode out into the dark carrying steel and faith like twin flames against the night. Walpole saw his own time was missing something. Something important that had gotten lost like a coin dropped in tall grass. He was living in troubled times when men's hearts had gone cold and their honor had dried up like creek beds in summer.

In his tale there's a man called Frederic who carries the old ways in him like embers in ash. Before you even meet him you know what he is. A prince who's suffered and bled and been thought dead at the hands of heathens. He's what knights was supposed to be, though Walpole made him larger than life, like a shadow cast by candlelight that stretches tall against a wall.

The chain moves like a great serpent through the world. From raw earth to finished goods it winds its way across the land leaving tracks of commerce in its wake. Oliver found it first back in 82, gave it a name though it had existed long before any man thought to call it such. Six parts to the beast: the making and the getting, the keeping and the placing, the moving and the knowing. All of it bound together like vertebrae in some ancient creature's spine.

The making comes first. Always has. Always will. Must know what's needed fore you can birth it into being. The market speaks if you know how to listen, tells you what folk hunger for in their bones. Managers stand like prophets reading signs in the wind, counting volume and quality like priests counting sacrificial lambs. Choose wrong and the whole thing falls to dust and ash. Seen it before in them big box stores where I done my time. Walmart. Target. Each one with their own scripture writ down in manuals thick as bibles, telling how every little thing ought be done from the way a man wears his clothes to how the trucks get emptied of their guts.

The getting comes next. Strategic they call it, like generals planning war. Deciding what each place can do best, what parts to keep close and what to send out to others. Sometimes you got to spread the work around, let other outfits take their piece. They call it velocity when they do that, though it ain't about speed so much as it's about being nimble while keeping the coin in your pocket. Like a man trying to dance quick without spilling his whiskey.

Each facility stands like its own fortress. Got its own soldiers with their own weapons, each one knowing their part in the greater war of commerce. Management looks down from high walls deciding where the strength lies, where the weakness shows. Sometimes they send the work away, let other armies fight them battles. All of it moving like blood through veins, keeping the great beast alive.

The books of that age bore the weight of detail like ornate Victorian mansions, all finery and aristocratic airs. But there were two that walked a darker path. Oliver Twist and Wuthering Heights. These carried something else in them. Something raw. Something that crept through the pages like a night-thing, unnamed and watchful. Mystery lived in their bones and the peculiar haunted their margins and this strangeness gave their people flesh and blood and hearts that beat true.

There was a passage where the boy Oliver walked in darkness. He moved between Sikes and Crackit like a ghost might walk between two demons arguing in hell. Their voices came to him across some vast distance though they stood at his shoulders. Then gunfire split the night and screaming rose up like birds scattered from a field. Lights bloomed in the dark. Pain lived in him then, deep and constant as breathing. Some unseen hand bore him away through this fever-dream of blood and noise and he could not fight it. Could not even try.

These nightmares they wrote into their books served different purposes but all showed the truth that lived beneath. In Oliver's tale they revealed what lay coiled in his heart, what ate at him in the dark hours, what whispered to him about the true nature of things. When they shot the boy and he relived it later it came back like a tide of darkness. No control did he have then. No power over his own destiny. The pain had made its home in him by then, wed to fear rather than shock. And through it all ran the question of whose will had brought him to this place, for surely it was not his own. The old jew Fagin had begun his work by then, breaking the boy piece by piece until despair became as natural as breathing. Even with death at his heels Oliver could not fight. Could not even try to save himself.

The day that followed was no day at all but merely night's brief absence. Then true night came again, somehow endless in its terrible silence yet fleeting in its hours, as if time itself had gone mad in the darkness.

There was a time I worked with the young ones, after their schooling was done for the day. Teaching them what little I knew. Reading mostly. English too. They sent me a boy named Adrian, dark eyes and quiet like they sometimes are. Third grade maybe fourth. Something wasnt right with the way he read. Letters all scattered in his mind like windblown leaves. Some he knew true and others might as well have been marks made by birds in the dust.

He spoke the English good enough. Clean and clear like any American child. Latino blood in him sure but you'd never know it from his speech. We worked at it, him and me, day after day until his mother came. It was during a field trip day and I was watching the ones left behind. She came in speaking no English at all. Just Spanish words falling soft like rain. My own Spanish was poor, broken things really, but we made do. And then I knew. Knew it like you know the coming of winter. The boy could read fine enough. Just not in English. The letters were foreign to him like tracks in the snow.

The language wall stands high in these schools. Higher in California than most places. Sometimes you cant even see it until youre right up on it. Even those that speak the English perfect as morning light, reading it can be like crossing a river in flood. Everyone knows this truth but knowing aint fixing.

For Adrian the path was clear enough. Teach him the letters. Show him the sounds they make. But for the others, the ones who barely know English at all, theres no simple answer. Dual language. Immersion. Special teachers. ESL. None of these alone will do it. You need them all together like fingers making a fist.

The dual language way, thats something worth considering. Not just for the Spanish speakers but all of them. Studies show these children do better than the rest. Some folk fear it. Say its wasteful. Say it wont help the majority. But thats not true. Make it the rule instead of the exception and watch them all rise. Dont need every teacher speaking both tongues. That aint realistic. But having some that do, special helpers who know both worlds, that might be the way. Might be the only way.

They tell you when youre small that theres something bigger than you are. Something you cant know with your mind. Some go to wooden buildings with crosses nailed to the walls and some go elsewhere and some just look inside themselves til their eyes go dark with looking. Most take what their people gave them like a worn coat passed down. Others spit on it all and say theres nothing but what they can hold in their own two hands. We take up one way of seeing then trade it for another like old coins we found in the dirt. No matter. We all walk that same road looking for that thing bigger than ourselves. Looking for some light in all that dark to lead us home.

Papa set in that old chair on the porch, rain coming down hard on the tin roof overhead. Sound like gravel in a metal drum. We smoked together and watched the rain drown them flowers along the porch edge where the gutters spilled. Asked him what bird he liked best and he said Cardinal and then he just stared out into that rain. Looking and not looking. Clothes hanging off him like someone elses skin. Hair thin now where it used to be thick. He wouldnt look at me and I couldnt speak the words that needed speaking. Words about missing and about loss. Speaking them would make the loss more real somehow. More final. I moved my chair closer to his. Hugged him once. Then we just watched that June rain come down in the growing dark.

He died in December. Five days after I turned twentytwo. They gave him radiation and poison to fight the thing growing inside him but it just made him suffer longer. I lay in bed nights asking what sort of God would do such a thing. No prayers came. If there was a God he'd stopped listening to me long ago.

I didnt watch him go. Didnt want to see the life that made my life drain away like water in sand. Wanted to remember him living not dying. Known him better than any of them anyway. Known he wouldnt want his boy watching death take him. So I curled up in my bed like some hurt animal and waited three days for word.

Word never came.

The man they called John Taylor of Caroline walked the fields of his plantation with purpose, knowing in his bones what the land could teach about freedom and governance. He was a farmer first and always would be, though the affairs of men had pulled him brief into their politics. The soil spoke to him of sovereignty and justice and the rights of men to work the earth as they saw fit.

He saw America raw and new like fresh-plowed ground, unencumbered by the dead weight of tradition that plagued the old world. Here was earth waiting to be seeded with self-governance. He knew about rights. Natural rights. How they tangled together like roots in rich soil, one failing and all failing, withering under the boot of government overreach. These were things no man should touch.

The state of nature, some called it. Taylor knew better. Knew how the strong and cunning would always prey upon the weak without the structures of civilization to bind them. But civilization itself was a double-edged blade.

He believed men carried both light and dark within them, good principles and bad bound together like wheat and chaff. Good principles protected what a man owned, nurtured the land, kept the money-changers at bay. Self-interest drove all men, he knew, but it turned poison when it led to parasitic sub-societies feeding off the public good.

Like many Republicans of his time he called for strict adherence to the Constitution, wanted federal power bound tight as a starving dog. He'd seen how bloated government bred despotism like flies on carrion. But simple reading of law wasn't enough - you had to know the mind of the men who wrote it. The Declaration, that was the true charter. It spoke of sovereign states, not one nation bound in iron chains of central control.

He knew these things bone-deep, like he knew the feel of soil crumbling between his fingers. The truth of it was in the land itself, in the sweat and toil of honest work. Everything else was just words floating away on the wind.

He stood there watchin the brown mass in the water below. Silent. Studying it with a detachment that came from years of such work. Thoughts like autumn leaves blown across an empty lot, there and gone again. His mind moved like water over stone, smooth and without purchase.

He remembered the art book. Some woman had give it to him years ago when he was still dreamin of bein an artist. Said it would teach him bout seein things proper. How to frame em up in your mind. Make em simpler. But there wasnt nothin simple about what he was lookin at now. No frame could contain it. Just stood there like a man before some terrible altar, his green tie hangin down like a hanged mans tongue.

If them old painters had their colors then this here was his. His testimony. His offering to whatever god watched over such things. Brown and perfect in its way. Like some cosmic joke played out in porcelain.

His hand found the handle. Pulled it. Watched the water swirl and eddy, clear as mountain stream water. The mass broke apart some but wouldnt go. Like it had made some covenant with the bowl. He flushed again. And again. Each time watchin the water rise and fall like the breath of some sleepin beast.

Finally he reached for the paper. Started wrappin his hand like them ancient peoples wrapped their dead. Layer after layer till his hand was swaddled in white. A priest preparin for some unholy sacrament. He bent at the waist, his arm descendin slow into them cool waters like a man reachin down into hell itself to shake hands with the devil.

The fluorescent lights hummed overhead. Silent witnesses to this ritual played out in a Rite Aid bathroom on some nameless Tuesday in a world that had long since stopped carin about such things. About the men who cleaned up after it. About anything at all.

They die behind the wheel. Young ones. Not yet grown. The statistics tell their tale in cold numbers but the dead speak nothing of their passing. The National Institutes say the young brain aint ready, like green wood that wont take a proper shape no matter how you work it. Inexperience kills them sure as any bullet. Their vehicles roll and speed and leave the road like wild things seeking their own destruction.

When they gather they die together. Like moths to flame. The California men who study such things showed it plain as day in their charts and papers. Numbers that tell of dead children stacked like cordwood.

The state men made their laws. Papers that say when the young ones can drive and who they can carry. As if paper could stop death. But these are just words written in offices by men who've forgotten what it was to be young and wild and immortal.

Even eighteen's too young says the doctor Zuckerman who studies such things. They seek the thrill like animals seeking water in drought, he says. They cant help themselves no more than a wolf can help howling at the moon. Wait till the blood cools, he says. Wait till they aint so ready to die.

More are coming. Children of the boom times growing up and reaching for keys like they was reaching for loaded guns. By 2010 theyll flood the roads like water breaking through a dam. Death rides shotgun with them all.

The fix aint hard to see though men make it seem so. Keep them learning in their schools but keep them off the roads till eighteen's past. Let them practice with their elders watching. Six hours behind the wheel and fifty more with someone who knows death's way. Make it the same in every state cause death dont care about state lines.

Some will say this aint new thinking. And they'd be right. Truth rarely is. But the dead dont care about new or old. They just stay dead all the same.
