The boy looked up at him and asked what was wrong with people who couldn't hear right. Not deaf folk, he said, but them that hear wrong somehow. The man studied the ashen sky before speaking.

They call it Central Auditory Processing Disorder, he said. CAPD. Where your ears work fine but your brain cant make sense of what it hears. Like trying to read tracks in the sand after the wind's got to them.

The boy thought about this. But they can hear?

Yes, the man said. They hear but the sounds get twisted somehow. Like looking through dirty glass. Everything's there but nothing's clear.

They sat watching the dead leaves scatter across the broken parking lot. The man remembered doctors from before. Men in white coats with clipboards who'd study children like they were reading maps to some foreign country. Testing them. Making them listen to sounds and words that came through headphones like distant echoes. Started back in the fifties, he said. Italian doctors. They'd put different words in each ear and watch what happened.

How do you know if someone has it?

Sometimes they cant tell where sounds come from. Like they're lost in space. Sometimes words get jumbled up. Or they cant hear someone talking if there's other noise. Like their brain cant sort out what's important.

The boy picked up a stick and drew in the dust. What happens to them?

They need help, the man said. Used to be teachers would know what to do. Special ways of teaching. Special places to sit in class. But that was before. Before all this.

He gestured at the wasteland around them. The boy nodded, understanding more than he should have to. They sat in silence for a while, listening to the wind move through the dead city.

The boy sat on her couch and he was sixteen and afraid and his eyes darted like small animals in a trap. He'd fled from them that raised him, them that should have loved him but didn't. I watched him there and knew what I had to do.

Years before I'd walked the halls of learning seeking knowledge of the mind and its workings. Studied the way folk cope with the darkness in them or flee from it or deny it altogether. Got my papers in Psychology but still the path ahead was dark and unknown like a road at night with no stars to guide by.

The next day I went to where his people lived. The police were there already, standing in the yard like sentinels in blue. I told them what I knew, told them of my learning in the ways of the mind. They bid me speak to the parents, said the law's hands were tied in such matters. The mother and father spoke in circles, nervous words about their boy being manipulative, about simple disputes made large. But their eyes told different tales. I knew then what I must become.

Justice is a thing we speak of but seldom see. We claim to value the singular soul but we make all souls alike, press them into shapes acceptable to the many. In my younger days I raged against this with wild-colored hair and metal in my flesh and clothes that spoke my truth. Stood with those that society cast aside - the different ones, the ones that loved different from the rest. Fought the old hatreds wherever I found them.

Now I aim to help the lost ones, the broken ones. To work with those cast aside by their own blood. My values are hewn from stone: service to others, respect for their dignity, truth in all dealings. These aren't just words but the very marrow of who I am. The path ahead is clear now, like a road at dawn with the sun rising blood-red in the east. I'll walk it and help who I can along the way.

He set the papers down before him and studied them in the dim light. Words about sleep and the wanting of it. The darkness that comes unbidden or not at all. He knew these things. The old doctors with their studies and their microscopes looking for answers in the brains of mice while all around them the world burned away to ash.

They called it insomnia but that word was just a marker for something deeper and more terrible. Something that lived in the blood and bones of men. In their very cells. The hypothalamus with its secret languages of sleep and waking. Neurons firing or not firing. The terrible democracy of consciousness that gave no quarter and took no prisoners.

He thought about the mice in their cages. The scientists watching them through glass walls while strange chemicals coursed through their blood. GABAB receptors. As if naming a thing gave you power over it. The mice slept or didn't sleep and men wrote down numbers in ledgers and thought they understood something about the night.

But there were other truths. Darker ones. The kind that lived in the spaces between people. In their histories and their bloodlines. In the weight of generations. Sleep disorders they called them. As if disorder wasnt the natural state of things. As if order was something more than a temporary rebellion against chaos.

The sociocultural model. The biological model. Words that tried to explain why some men slept while others lay awake counting their breaths in the dark. But they were just words. The truth was in the darkness itself. In the terrible silence between heartbeats. In the long hours before dawn when a man could feel the weight of all his ancestors pressing down on him like stones.

He thought about the people who couldn't sleep. How they moved through the world like ghosts. How their days bled into their nights until time itself became meaningless. School. Work. The rituals of the living. All of it just shadows on the wall of a cave that got deeper and darker with each passing hour.

Been here at University Park going on three years now. Time moves like a slow river through the valley of days. When I first come here they put me in East Halls, far out on the edge of everything where the wind blows cold and merciless across empty fields. Beyond lay only the stadium and the center they call Bryce Jordan, standing like ancient monuments to some forgotten civilization.

The walk from Stuart Hall to Willard building was a pilgrimage through wasteland, twenty-five minutes if the weather held, longer when the sky turned black and the rain came sideways like it does in State College. An old timer told me once how East Halls used to stand alone out there, separated from everything by dead ground that stretched on forever. Now they've filled it all in. Sports fields. New buildings risen up like concrete monoliths. The Creamery. Health services. Apartment blocks circled round like wagons against the night.

The campus grows like some mindless thing, devouring space, making distance where there was none before. But there's an answer to this vastness. The bicycle. Simple as scripture. Mechanical and true. Though the machine itself aint worth nothing without riders to push the pedals, and paths to ride upon.

Friend of mine took up riding again after years away from it. Said he couldn't recollect why he ever stopped. "Only way to get around," he said, like he'd discovered some profound truth written in steel and rubber. And he wasnt wrong. Bowl of oatmeal and muscle gets you thirty miles. Maybe more.

I live off campus now, far as any dorm. Got myself a bike. Best decision I ever made in this place. Thomas building's my daily destination. Twenty-five minute walk but five minutes riding if you're willing to push. Pollock Road's the straightest shot but it aint always favorable. Could walk, I suppose, if I was of a mind to waste time. But time's a currency I cant afford to spend. Thirty minutes extra each way. Two and a half hours gone each week, vanished like smoke in the wind. More when you count everything else. Time's too precious for that kind of waste.

He sat there in the dim light reading the words about the world that was to come. A world of machines and men who were no longer men. The book spoke of a controller who watched over all things like some dark god. In this world there was no love. No hatred neither. Just the endless consumption of things that meant nothing at all.

The people there were born into their stations like cattle bred for slaughter. Each one marked from birth to serve their purpose and nothing more. They called it conditioning but it was slavery plain and simple. The lower orders knew nothing of their chains. Kept docile with drugs and empty pleasures while those above them pulled the strings.

He thought about how the classes moved among each other like ghosts. No true touching. No true knowing. The men spoke of women like they were things made of air and flesh and nothing more. Pneumatic was the word they used. As if the curves of a woman's body were something to be measured like tire pressure. The women no better. Speaking of their couplings like discussing the weather or what they had for breakfast.

Each class stayed in its place like layers in a cake gone stale. The high born alphas and betas looking down from their towers while the others scurried below. All of them prisoners though most didnt know it. Kept in line with promises of happiness that was no happiness at all. Just pleasure without meaning. Without cost. Without pain.

The controller stood above it all like some dark spider in its web. Watching. Waiting. Feeding them all the same sweet poison that kept them docile and consuming and believing they were free when they were anything but. A machine built of flesh and bone and blood that ground on and on toward nothing at all except its own perpetuation.

He closed the book and sat there in the growing dark thinking about how the world was headed down that same road. How men were becoming less than men. How love was dying. How the things that made us human were being stripped away one by one until nothing would be left but the hollow shell of what we once were. And he knew that this was what the writer had seen coming all those years ago. This was what he had tried to warn us about. But who would listen. Who would care. Who would even understand.

Four years past I sat in a room learning of Islam and its ways. The question hung heavy in the air like smoke, whether this faith carried violence in its heart. More pressing now than ever it seems, watching the world turn and darken since them towers fell. The papers and screens that once spoke with venom against the faithful now bend backwards in tolerance, as if afraid of their own shadow. Strange days indeed when a man called Barack Obama, with Islam running through his blood like a dark river, could reach for the highest seat in the land.

The Prophet's tale troubles me some. What they write of him and what history shows stand apart like two strangers eyeing each other across a dusty street. In my mind I see him as he was, sword in hand, forcing men to kneel and accept his truth or taste steel. Yet here in these pages he walks soft, humble as a child, drawing men to him like moths to flame. They paint him martyr-like, misunderstood, bearing his burden in silence while truth worked its way through men's hearts.

There's something that ain't right about how they mirror the Christ's works in Muhammad's deeds. They tell of him making meat and milk stretch beyond nature's bounds, feeding forty men where there was food for few. It reads false, like a man trying to wear another's skin. They diminish the true miracle of Jesus, stealing his glory to dress their prophet in borrowed light.

The stories they tell come handed down through too many mouths, like water poured from cup to cup until you can't trust what's left. This man told that man who heard from another - truth gets thin when stretched so far. They mean it as proof but it reads like smoke and mirrors, each telling making the tale more suspect.

What gnaws at me most is how they fashion him gentle and wise, a shepherd leading his flock with soft words and softer heart. But history speaks different. It speaks of blood and steel and conquest. Sometimes I wonder if the faithful today know the truth of it, or if they too believe in this phantom prophet, this ghost of gentleness that never was.

The words of the Christ and what he held true in his days upon the earth were cast aside like dead leaves in the wind that followed. If you were to stand upon some high place and look down across the vastness of time you'd see how the truth of it all just kept moving further and further away like some dream you cant quite remember when you wake. These days there's a knowing in people. A different kind of knowing that wasn't there before. The old ones who cling to what their fathers told them and their fathers before them still remain but they're getting fewer, like dying embers in a cold hearth.

Among them that call themselves Christian there's going to be an awakening. Like water rising slow and steady in some ancient well. They'll start peeling away at what men added to the words. Layer by layer. Year by year. Maybe it'll take generations but it'll come sure as night follows day. The clock of time spinning backwards until there aint nothing left but what he said. What he meant. Before the others came with their own ideas about God.

When this tide sweeps through the lands of the white man it'll wash clean the churches but wont destroy them. They'll still stand like weathered sentinels. But something strange will happen. All them differences between believers will start fading away like footprints in the sand when the tide comes in. History's got a way of turning back on itself. Like how Rome went from killing Christians to bowing before their cross. Or how this country went from keeping men in chains to letting them lead.

You go back far enough and there was just the Jews. That's where it all started. Before Christ walked the earth they had their one God and their holy books and their laws handed down since Moses' time. Back when Rome took Jerusalem in the year 63 before Christ the Jews weren't of one mind neither. They had their divisions. Sadducees. Pharisees. Essenes. Zealots. And then there was just the common folk, carrying their beliefs like stones in their pockets, wearing them smooth with worry and wonder.

They was greed in them and it was a thing that could not be denied nor cast out. Like some darkness that dwelled in the heart of man since time was time. The Jungle showed this truth plain as day. Showed it in the way men conducted their affairs and in the way they turned their eyes from the suffering of others like it was nothing to them at all.

The factory men stood highest among these. Lords of their concrete kingdoms rising black against the sky, smoke pouring forth like the breath of some industrial beast. Sinclair wrote of them chimneys standing against the heavens, smoke streaming endless to the edge of the world as if God himself had blessed their venture. But there was no blessing in it. Only the slow poisoning of everything that drew breath.

They cared nothing for the workers that made their fortunes. Nothing for the men and women broken on the wheels of progress. The whole of Packingtown was nothing but a cauldron of hate and desperation where a man's worth was measured against a dollar and found wanting. They'd lay off hundreds without warning, casting them into the streets like so much offal. No law stood between the workers and their masters in them days. No protection from the speed-ups and the dangerous machines and the bone-grinding labor that left men dead before their time.

The people who lived and died there had no choice but to endure. Like chattel they was, bound to the factories by hunger and desperation. Foreign folks mostly, hanging by a thread over starvation's abyss, their fates tied to the whims of men no better than slave drivers of old. And like slavery it bred a particular kind of darkness in the soul. A corruption that spread through them streets like a disease, touching everything it encountered. Making monsters of men who might otherwise have been decent folk.

Them factory owners stood atop it all like kings of old, counting their money while below them the masses suffered. They breathed different air than the working folk. Ate different food. Their children played in parks while the children of the workers played in gutters filled with offal and blood from the killing floors. That was the way of it. The natural order they'd created, as merciless as nature herself.

In the darkened corridors of literary history there was a poem called Dream-land and Poe had writ it and called it among his finest works. The word Thulé lay buried in its verses like some ancient rune, appearing twice as though summoned from older tongues. Mabbott traced it back to Virgil who spoke of lands beyond the edge of knowing, an isle north of Britain where the known world gave way to darkness and myth. But there were other wells from which such waters might have sprung.

The German writers had caught Poe's eye and mind both. Their words like cold iron striking flame in the darkness of his thoughts. Goethe chief among them, his Faust a thing of terrible beauty published in two parts, the first in 1808 and the last in the year of his death, 1832. Within that second part lay "The King of Thulé" like a dark jewel. It told of a king whose queen had passed leaving him naught but a goblet and his grief. He drank deep of both till at last he cast the cup into the sea and followed after, his eyes closing on the world forever.

The shadows between these works ran deep as wells. Dream-land and The King of Thulé stood as mirror-dark reflections, each echoing loss and loneliness and the color leaching out of all things. The speaker in Dream-land walked as though he'd stepped into Goethe's world itself, seeing what that ancient king had seen, feeling what he had felt in those last moments on the cliff's edge.

Goethe's name carried weight that even Poe could not ignore. When asked of Tennyson, Poe spoke of both men in the same breath, their words carrying across oceans and years in endless adaptations and tellings. The darkness in their verses called to his own, and in Dream-land that darkness found its echo, twice-told and terrible in its beauty.

The law spoke of malice and rights and obligations but the store manager knew none of these things. He sat in his office that October evening eating his dinner while the applesauce lay spilled across the cold linoleum like some pale viscous blood. First came Wayne telling him of the danger and then Haddigan but he paid them no mind. The food was warm in his mouth and he had no time for such things. No time at all.

The woman Palmer came through at half past five walking the fluorescent aisles like a pilgrim in some retail wasteland. She didnt see the spill. How could she. The floor was slick and treacherous and she went down hard onto the tiles, her spine cracking like green wood in winter. Behind the security cameras watched with their dead glass eyes recording everything and nothing.

There had been others before her. Five souls who'd fallen in that same store that year alone. Their bodies hitting the floor like sacks of wet cement. Each time the manager had known. Each time he had chosen to look away. The law called it conscious disregard but it was something older than that. Something primitive and dark that lived in the spaces between duty and indifference.

In California the statutes spoke of punitive damages for acts committed with oppression fraud or malice. Cold words for cold deeds. The courts had ruled on such things before. They knew malice when they saw it. Knew it in the willful turning away from consequence. Knew it in the deliberate blindness to the rights of others. The manager had seen the danger coming like storm clouds on the horizon but he had chosen to let it come. Let whatever would happen happen.

The judge would have to look at it now. Would have to weigh the despicable nature of it. Six people fallen. Six bodies broken on his watch. The manager sitting in his office that evening spooning food into his mouth while danger waited in the aisles like some patient predator. No. This wasnt something that could be dismissed with the wave of a gavel. The malice lay there as plain as the spilled applesauce on the store floor. As plain as the broken woman who now sought her justice.

The wanting had been there since she was fourteen. A hollow thing that wouldnt be filled. Three years gone now and still it gnawed at her like some dark beast crouched in the chambers of her heart. Not a thing she needed but someone. The boys came and went like pale ghosts. Their awkward advances met with silence. She studied herself in the mirror nights, questioning what darkness lay within that made her this way. No answers came.

The house was quiet most days. Her mother and father walked soft through the rooms like spirits themselves, rarely raising voices against each other or their daughter save when she blazed forth with that wild fire that burned in her. A fire they hadnt known the source of. She carried it like a torch through the world and folk were drawn to its light.

But this day the quiet broke. A scream tore through the morning air from the kitchen where her mother stood. The girl ran. Mama she called. Mama what is it. Her mother lay twisted on the tile floor making small animal sounds of pain. The girl knelt beside her and laid hands on her mothers shoulder. Hospital the mother said through gritted teeth. The girl gathered her up like a child, grateful for the strength in her arms, and carried her through the door to the waiting car.

The hospital reeked of spirits and sick folk and death but she paid it no mind. Carried her mother through the sliding doors calling out for help in a voice that echoed off the sterile walls. White coats descended like vultures. They took her mother away on a rolling bed and left the girl alone with her thoughts in the waiting room where the fluorescent lights buzzed overhead like angry wasps.

Later they told her how her mother had fallen reaching for some old pottery piece high up in the kitchen cabinets. As if such things mattered now. As if anything mattered but the soft rise and fall of her mothers chest in the hospital bed. The girl sat vigil through the night watching. Watching and waiting while outside the window the world spun on uncaring through the dark.

They sought to know of hearts and their failings and of the old ways of eating that might keep a man from the darkness that comes with disease. The Mediterranean way they called it though it wasnt really about the sea at all but about the things that grew from the earth and the creatures that swam in those waters. The old people who lived there knew things about food that the modern world had forgotten. They ate the fruits of trees and grains from the field and fish from the waters and they drank wine in moderation as men have done since time out of mind.

They watched seventy four thousand women for twenty years. Nurses they were all of them. Each two years time they would write down what they ate and what they drank and the watchers would give them numbers based on how close they kept to the old ways. The women grew older. Some sickened and died. Some had their hearts give out and some had their minds stolen by clots in their brains that came silent and terrible in the night.

The watchers kept their vigil through all those years marking down in their books when one would fall. They checked the death papers and the hospital records and sometimes even the cut flesh itself to be certain of what had taken each one. When they could not be certain they marked it probable and kept counting anyway for that was all they could do.

They found that those who kept closest to the old ways were less likely to be taken. The numbers showed it clear as day. Of those who ate as their ancestors had eaten only seventy one of every hundred suffered what the others did. The rest were spared though no one could say why exactly. Perhaps it was the earth itself protecting those who still remembered how to eat of it properly. Perhaps it was something else entirely. Something older. Something that had been waiting in the blood since before men knew how to write such things down.

The numbers told their story but numbers are just shadows on paper and paper burns and shadows fade and in the end all that remains is what was and what wasnt and the long dark road between the two.

The sign said Hitler lived in Burma and the girl held it overhead like some proclamation of doom. She stood alone on that corner in the gray morning light, the cardboard sign stark against the pallid sky. The words were writ in black marker, crude and prophetic.

Burma. Myanmar they called it now. A land of old temples and new terrors where men in olive drab had seized power years past, their rifles still warm from the taking. The monks came first in their robes color of flame and sunset. Saffron Revolution, they named it. As if revolution could be distilled to mere color. The people followed after, drawn to the monks like moths to fire until the streets filled with their prayers and their rage.

The junta watched and waited. Patient as serpents. Then they struck. They came in the night for the monasteries, boots on ancient stone, rifle butts splintering temple doors that had stood centuries. They gathered the foreign press like cattle, herded them into cells. One Japanese man lay dead in the street, his camera still clicking its last frames as his blood spread black on the pavement. Thirteen dead said the papers. But the colonel who fled spoke of thousands. Bodies stacked like cordwood in the jungle. The earth drinks deep of such offerings.

It was nothing new under the sun. Since men first built walls they sought to rule what lay within them. Roman emperors crowned themselves with divinity. Japanese kings claimed celestial birth. Even now our leader takes counsel from prophets of folly, their words carried on wires across the continent like the muttering of ghosts.

The dead keep their own accounts. In China they gathered in the square that June, students and workers crying freedom into the dawn until the tanks came grinding through the night. Two hundred said the state. Three thousand said the truth. In Rwanda they killed with machetes, neighbor against neighbor until the streets ran red. And before them all came Hitler with his camps and his chambers and his dream of racial purity bought with smoke and ash.

The girl stood holding her sign. The wind moved her hair. Above, the sky threatened rain. Some truths cant be buried, no matter how deep you dig the grave.

He sat at that piano like a man possessed of something darker than mere talent. The legacy of Duke Ellington aint just in the years he spent making that music but in how he shaped and molded them players like clay in his hands. His own playing was quiet. Subtle. Like whispers in the night. But when he wrote them pieces they came out rich and complex as blood, each one crafted special for them men who played em.

He knew what each man could do. Knew it deep in his bones. Built frameworks where they could blow free as birds but then hed write these tight orchestrated parts that called on what was particular to each player. Something in their soul that needed telling. The whole orchestra had a sound like nothing else in this world. Original. Pure. Each piece different but carrying that same blood through its veins.

Take that Creole Love Call. Voice used like any other instrument might be. No words to get in the way of what needed saying. Six parts to it like this:

First theres that call and response tween voice and reeds. Smooth at first then turning rough like old leather. Then comes a muted trumpet crying out blue notes that'd break your heart. High clarinet floating over piano next, then the whole band taking up that first theme again. Fifth part building like a storm with them reeds calling high and brass answering like thunder. Last part going back to where it started, voice turning to something else entirely. Something that growled like some night creature. Brief ending like a whispered goodbye.

Hot and Bothered came later. Miley on that muted trumpet speaking back and forth with Baby Cox's voice, neither one quite human nor quite instrument but something in between. It Don't Mean a Thing brought Nanton in, man they called Tricky Sam, working that trombone like it was speaking in tongues.

This was the sound of something being born in American music. Something that hadnt been there before and wouldnt never be there quite the same way again. Dark and beautiful and terrible all at once. Like watching the sun go down on the last day of the world.

He sat there studying the shell like some ancient thing pulled from the earth's deep memory. The whorl of it spiraling through time and space like the thoughts of dead men. Like the thoughts of God himself. The columella running through its heart like a spine, each turn marking the passage of time in calcium and death. He knew there were laws to such things. Mathematical certainties that men like Thompson had tried to capture with numbers and equations back in 1917 though they might as well have been trying to measure the soul.

The shell lay there in the pale light. Its aperture gazing up like some blind eye, each whorl growing larger as it spiraled outward from that first beginning, that point where life had started its slow accretion of being. The sutures between each turn marked clear as property lines on some dead man's map. Body whorl fat and final like the period at the end of a death sentence.

He turned it in his hands. Apical view showing the spiral from above, then basal, then apertural with its opening like a mouth frozen mid-speech. Could count the whorls if you knew how. Draw a line through its heart and follow the spiral out, marking quarter turns like time on some cosmic clock.

The trajectory of it all could be mapped. Could be measured and marked with numbers that meant something to men who believed such things could be contained in mathematics. But he knew better. Knew that evolution moved like water over stone, wearing away at the edges of possibility until something new emerged from the darkness. Like those Prunum shells they studied with their X-rays and computers, trying to divine the boundaries of what could be from what was.

The shell sat heavy in his hand. Each whorl a perfect geometric progression through space, each turn following laws old as stone. Laws that men like Stone tried to capture in programs like CerioShell, thinking they could model life's possibilities like architects planning cities. But the truth was in the shell itself. In the cold calcium spiral that had once housed life, now empty as a desert church.

He set it down gentle as laying a child to rest. The mathematics of it all meant nothing really. Just men trying to measure the immeasurable, to contain the infinite in finite terms. The shell would keep its secrets. Would stay mute as bone while men scratched equations in the dust, trying to understand why life moves as it does through the long dark of time.

They sat there in the dim light of the office studying the numbers on the page. Numbers that told of death. Of children lost. Of mothers gone. Indonesia. A place far off where the sun rose first and where death stalked the villages and towns like some dark specter that would not rest.

Ten years gone and nothing changed. The dying went on. While some things got better like water and ways to keep clean the children kept dying and the mothers too. Too many to count. Too many to bear. He looked at the paper again. The reasons written there in black ink that told nothing of the truth of it.

Seventy-two percent they said. Birth helpers there to catch the babies as they came into the world. But these weren't doctors. Just women who knew the old ways. When the blood came they could do nothing but watch it flow. Watch the mothers slip away into that dark country from which no traveler returns.

In the cities things were better. Seven births cut from the belly for every hundred. In the country only two. The numbers told their own story. The rich lived. The poor died. Twenty-seven percent difference between them that had and them that didn't. Money bought life. Always had.

He thought about the programs they wanted to build. Vertical they called them. Like towers reaching up into nothing. But you couldn't build towers without foundations and the foundations weren't there. The system was broken. Had always been broken. Would stay broken until someone fixed it proper.

They'd seen it before. Money flowing like water into one thing. AIDS they called it. Death by another name. While the family planning dried up and blew away like dust in the wind. People followed the money. Always had. Always would. Made more paperwork. More forms. More ways to count the dead.

The numbers stared back at him from the page. Cold. Implacable. Like the eyes of something that lived in the deep dark places of the earth. Something that fed on suffering. On death. On the tears of mothers holding their dead children. He folded the paper and put it away. Some things you couldn't fix with numbers. Some things you couldn't fix at all.

The dark waters of popular music run deep and cold now, deeper than any man could count in years. A hundred winters have passed and still the genres multiply like vermin in the night, breeding new forms that crawl forth into the light. Rap and rock and country and jazz and folk, each one spawning bastard children of their own, sub-genres writhing beneath sub-genres until the names mean nothing at all.

But it was Heavy Metal that grew the blackest roots, spreading like some malignant vine through forty years of American soil. They say it speaks in tongues of darkness, voices that carry pain and rage and something older still. Something that was there before the music, before the instruments, before the men who played them.

The metal came like a storm in the night and when it passed nothing was the same. Men took what they found in its wake and forged new sounds, hammered them into shapes that had no names. Now the metal runs in so many streams that no man can say where one ends and another begins. To know the truth of it you got to go back to the source, back to where it first came bubbling up from the ground like black oil.

Metal carries darkness in its bones. More of everything - more thunder in the bass, more violence in the strings, more blood in the throat of every singer. These weren't no primitive howlers neither. These were craftsmen who knew their tools like a hunter knows his rifle. And there were drugs too, oh yes. Mid-seventies saw a flood of chemicals that turned men's minds inside out, made them see things that weren't there and hear music that hadn't existed before. They blamed it on the drugs but the darkness was in them all along, waiting.

The old music had been afraid to look into that darkness. But metal stared right into it, reached in and pulled out something raw and bleeding. Like them old Romantic composers who wrote about death and devils, only now it came through amplifiers tall as men, through speakers that could shatter glass. Even the Beatles caught that fever. Their song Helter Skelter came crawling out like something born in a cave, all teeth and hunger. They'd heard what the Stones were doing and wanted to prove they could swim in those same black waters. They did too, though some say that's where the trouble started.

He came before them all, before them dreampainters with their wild visions, Henri Rousseau crafting his own dreams both in sleep and wake. The Dream they called it, made in 1910, showing a woman laid bare in wonderment at some savage paradise, but it was Rousseau's own dreaming too that lived there on that canvas. Recognition he sought, acceptance from them that made art and them that loved it, but the path to such things was dark and winding and full of thorns.

The Dream stood testament to his struggle, that war between conforming to what others wanted and walking alone down his own dark road. Born in Laval in 1844 to a tinsmith who had some money but not much else. No schooling in art did he receive, worked forty years as a gabelou collecting coins at the town gates though they called him douanier like he was something more than he was. His first wife Clémence died after watching eight babies go into the ground, leaving him with just Julia and a grief that sat in his chest like a stone. Painting became his refuge, his escape from the darkness that surrounded him.

He wasnt like them other painters who made pretty pictures of peasants with their romantic notions. He was of the folk and painted like the folk, carrying their hopes in his hands like water. His wanting to be accepted by them art folk was a thing you could understand if you looked at it right. No education had he in the ways of painting and was old when he started, working alongside them that had made names for themselves already.

Matisse was rising then, when Rousseau finally got some notice. Gordon wrote in his book about modern French painters that these two men were different as night and day. Matisse feared painting like others painted while Rousseau wanted nothing more than to make pictures so proper and right that the Artiste Français would open their doors to him. But doors dont open easy for men like him, men who carry dreams in their pockets like copper pennies, hoping someday they might turn to gold.

He sat there thinking on them that came before, them that spoke of truth and beauty being bound together like twins in the womb. Couldn't say why exactly but he reckoned there was something to it. Old Keats had written it down plain as day on some Greek pot, said beauty was truth and truth was beauty and that was all any man needed to know in this world. Most things a man learns come from books or hard living but these things, these notions of right and wrong and what makes something fine to look at, they come from somewhere deeper. Like they was already there waiting to be found.

He thought on how folk try to explain these things, breaking them down into little pieces like a butcher with a carcass. They'd take apart a painting or a deed and name all its parts but never get to the heart of it. Like that painting of the woman with the strange smile. People talked about light and shadow and history but none of that told you why it made your chest tight to look at it. Most times when you asked someone why they loved some piece of art they'd just say there was something about it, something they couldn't put their finger on. Like trying to describe the taste of water.

O'Connor, she knew. Said some things couldn't be told straight out, had to come sideways through a story. No matter how many words you used there was always something left over, something that wouldn't get caught in the net of language. Same with knowing right from wrong. That Austrian fella Wittgenstein said you couldn't even speak it proper, said it was beyond words altogether.

The connection twixt the two, between what's right and what's beautiful, it lived in that space beyond words. Hit you in a place you couldn't point to, like a ghost touching your heart. Books though, they was different. McKean had it right when he said books was special cause they carried the weight of living in them. Values, he called them. Said that's what made books matter, cause they showed us how to be human in a world that sometimes forgot what that meant.

Sitting there in the growing dark he thought on all this. Thought about how some truths was like smoke, visible but impossible to hold. How beauty and goodness was tied together like a knot that couldn't be undone. And maybe that's all any man needed to know.

The land stretches vast and cold beneath a gray sky that hangs like a burial shroud from München to the dark waters of Kiel. A country now but once it was nothing but blood and soil and the ghosts of ancient tribes that walked these grounds. The culture moves like a river through the heart of it all, from Köln where the Rhine cuts deep to Dresden where the Elbe winds slow and methodical through stone.

They called it Germania once. The old ones did. The name itself lost to time and the whispers of dead scholars who argued its meaning in candlelit rooms now turned to dust. Tacitus wrote of the Tungrians, how they crossed the Rhine with blood in their eyes and war in their hearts. Caesar knew them too. Called them Germanus in his writings, marking them separate from the Gauls he'd broken beneath Roman boots. Some say the word meant neighbor in the tongue of the Gauls. Others speak of spears called ger, or the battle cry that split the air like thunder.

Tacitus wrote more. His words scratched onto parchment in 98 AD telling of a people pure as winter snow, untouched by the blood of others. Who would come here, he asked, to this wild land of bitter skies and darker hearts? Only those born to it. Only those who knew nothing else.

The Romans came though. Came and went like storms across the land, taking what they could carry, leading men to die in foreign soil. But they always returned to their marble columns and paved roads, leaving Germania to those who knew its ways. The tribes lived on the edge of empire, trading forest gold and warrior blood, serving in legions not their own while the years turned slow as millstones grinding all to dust.

The play stretched out before him like some vast tapestry of deception and truth woven together in threads of gold and shadow. He watched it unfold in his mind, the way disguise worked its dark magick through the characters like a slow poison or a balm depending on how you held it to the light. Truth was they all wore masks. Every last one of them. And underneath those masks lay other masks still, peeling away layer by layer until what remained was either salvation or damnation.

He thought about Viola mostly. How she'd shed her woman's skin like a snake in winter, taking on man's flesh not out of want but necessity. The foreign shore had teeth and she knew it. "I'll bring you to a captain in this town," she'd said, voice already changing like the tide, "Where lie my maiden weeds." Protection, yes. But protection carries its own price.

The deception worked its way through the story like a dark river cutting through stone. It isolated her from the women, left her adrift in a sea of complications. Olivia's love came at her sideways, mistaking her for Sebastian: "Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay." Words thrown like stones across still water. And Orsino with his thousand declarations, never knowing the truth that stood before him in borrowed clothes: "Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times/ Thou never shouldst love woman like to me."

He considered how the modern eye might see it different. How deception sometimes forces truth from its hiding place like smoke from a burrow. Olivia's desire for Cesario might mean something deeper, something hidden beneath the surface like old bones in river mud. But more likely it spoke to the foolishness of those who judge by the shell and not the meat within. When Sebastian appeared she transferred her love quick as summer lightning, and Cesario became sister instead of lover: "A sister, you are she." Simple as that. Clean as a knife cut.

The truth was masks served their purpose until they didn't. Then they had to fall away like dead skin or they'd grow into the flesh permanent-like, and a person would forget what lay beneath. That was the real danger. Not the wearing but the forgetting.

They called it German rule but there wasnt nothing German about the dead. The Ovaherero. The Nama. Names like cold stones in the mouth. Dust and bones scattered in that hardscrabble land where the empire had come and gone like some dark caravan bearing death in its wagons. But empires aint built on simple things and this was no different. Each colony carved from earth and blood had its own way. Its own truth.

In the east they found them reading. Africans with books in their hands like relics from some forgotten time. The British who came after spoke of it. How the Germans had built schools there. How they had taught them. But in the southwest there was nothing. Just mission houses scattered like broken teeth in a dead mans skull where the churches did what they could with what little they had. The Germans built fine schools there too but they werent for the natives. No. They were for the white children. The settlers children. Their bloodline preserved in brick and mortar while the African children watched from beyond the fence where their futures lay scattered in the dust like spent cartridges.

He thought about the numbers sometimes. Fifteen thousand whites in the southwest by 1913. More than anywhere else in their African holdings. The climate drew them like flies to meat. Not gentle but livable. Desert stretched its fingers across the land but a man could survive there. Could build something. But what they built was a wall. A wall between knowing and not knowing. Between reading and not reading. Between being and not being.

The books told it different ways. Most in German text, written when the empire still breathed. Later the English came with their own tellings. Their own comparisons. Cohen wrote of it. How the settlers made the difference. How their presence shaped everything like wind shapes stone. But there was more to it than that. There always is. Dark truths buried in darker soil. Waiting.

In the east they learned. In the west they didnt. Simple as that but nothing is simple. Nothing at all.

They called it fifty-seven years. From eighteen thirty-six to eighteen ninety-three the blood flowed between them like some ancient biblical curse. Two nations locked in their death dance across the desert wastes. America and Mexico. Each carrying their own god in their teeth like mad dogs.

The war came in forty-six. American boots marking time across Mexican soil while the desert sun watched indifferent and cruel. When it was done Texas lay in American hands and with it the great southwestern wastes. But the blood didnt stop there. It wouldnt stop for years yet.

They were different peoples carrying different gods. The Americans with their protestant prayers and the Mexicans with their Catholic saints. Like old world hatreds carried across the sea in the holds of wooden ships. The English and Spanish had passed down their ancient feuds like some dark inheritance and now their children played out those old wars in new lands.

Seventeen times they clashed proper in those years. Border raids and frontier justice dealing death in small measures. Bandits and outlaws moving like wraiths across the invisible lines men had drawn in the sand. Lines meant nothing to them. They killed and stole and vanished back across the border leaving nothing but ash and bone behind.

The rivalry died slow like everything else in that hard country. Mexico grew dependent on American gold and the American dream changed from land to commerce. Some things dont die clean. They linger like ghosts haunting the margins of ledger books and trade agreements. The desert remembers though. Every drop of blood spilled there marks the sand forever and the wind carries the memories of dead men in its teeth.

Fifteen years back the sickness came. Not gradual like most things that take you down but swift and merciless as a hangman's drop. I didn't even know such afflictions existed in the world.

I was a nurse then. Chose it out of some deep hollow need for safety, the kind that never came in childhood. They'd tell you nursing was sure as sunrise. People getting sick and dying, that's what people do. So I buried my dreams of science and words and took up with the sick and dying. Like making a deal with death himself.

Now here I was. Forty-six years gone from birth, alone in the world save for my affliction, bank account empty as a desert well. Fifteen years living off the government's mercy and everything I ever called mine has turned to dust. Each dawn brings its own war against fear and worthlessness. Nothing certain anymore except uncertainty itself. But there's one truth that stands like bedrock: without my blood kin and the few true souls who stayed, I'd have been carried off by the dark waters long ago. When disaster comes it strips you bare, leaves you naked as a newborn in the cold world.

Life's got its ambush points. No map shows where they lay waiting. You can fill your storehouse to the rafters but some storms are too big for one soul to weather alone.

These days folks talk about standing alone against the world, like them pioneers who crossed the mountains west. But that ain't the truth of it. What kept them wagon trains rolling wasn't the strength of one man but the bonds between many. Compassion and respect, the sharing of what little they had. Nobody crossed them mountains alone.

So yes, keep your disaster kit. Stack your canned goods and matches. Lay in water tablets and medical supplies like you're preparing for the end times. Plant your garden if you've got the ground for it. But while you're building your fortress against what's coming, remember this: know your neighbor's face. Learn their story. Because when the real darkness comes, it ain't gonna be you alone against it. It'll be all of us or none.

In the old world before the old world there was a prince. They called him Buddha later but that wasnt his name then. He walked out of his palace one day and never went back. Found something in himself that wasnt there before. Something that burned like a coal in the deepest part of night. Twenty five hundred years gone now and the religion he built stands different. Changed. In Sri Lanka they cut the water every year. Some ceremony. Monks in their robes like old ghosts moving through the current. Buddha never spoke of such things but there it is all the same. The changes run deeper than ceremony. Run down to the marrow of what they believe. What they think will save them.

The changes came from within and without. Like a sickness. Some meant harm and others didnt care either way but the changes came all the same. Inside the walls of their temples the monks watched it happen. Outside the merchants and farmers and all manner of men watched too. Some fought it. Others didnt.

At the heart of it all three things. Buddha himself. The Dhamma which is their holy word written in three parts. The Sangha which is their church if you could call it that. The books tell em what they need to know. How to live. What rules to follow. What lies behind the veil of the world. They say theres no soul. Say life is suffering. Say nothing lasts. Round and round they go dying and being born again until they figure it out. Until they shake off want and hate and being blind to what is real.

The monks got their rules and the common folk got theirs. Five things they cant do. Cant kill. Cant lie. Cant steal. Cant do wrong with their bodies. Cant poison their minds with drink or worse things. But at the bottom of it all four truths like old stones in a dry riverbed. Life is pain. Want causes pain. Pain can end. Theres a way out if youre strong enough to take it.

original_texts:
Culture plays a significant role in any negotiation. Culture can be defined as much by what it is not as what it actually is and what it signifies. Culture is not homogenous, nor is it a specific thing. It is also not singular or uniform. Statements such as “all Russians are stubborn” or “all Japanese are accommodating,” are inherently broad and overly simplistic. While the understanding of a culture’s generalizations are appropriate, it is much more productive to a negotiator to understand the significance of a culture to the matter at hand, and how that culture’s attitude can and will affect the table talks. When one approaches a foreign culture, one experiences it in a way that is relatable to his own culture, and comparisons necessarily arise. 

Attempting to understand a foreign culture or mindset can involve anything from studying its history to realizing its prejudices. Rather than judging or attempting to change a culture, one must simply accept it for what it is, and work within its boundaries, especially within the scope of negotiation, and most especially if one comes to the table with a weaker bargaining position. Likewise, if a negotiator finds himself on “away” territory, a respect for traditions and beliefs can only help in getting over any cultural barriers and move the negotiation forward.

It is important to note that culture does not necessarily limit itself to a national/international dichotomy. Most companies within a given nation establish their own corporate culture. For instance, a corporate culture might emphasize long hours in the office or a more relaxed schedule. Evidence of a corporate culture can be seen in employee dress codes, in communication style (direct v. indirect communication, delegation of duties), and hiring practices. Some companies encourage philanthropy at any level from employees, others restrict it to “company approved” charities or fundraisers. One need only look at the differences in American corporate culture from company to company (and indeed, intra-company diversity exists even from region to region, urban to suburban environments included) to appreciate the diversity of thought that can reside within a particular societal culture. Certain cultures are not nearly as stratified as American culture, and may appear more uniform to an outsider, but a similar exterior is simply a sign to dig deeper. 

Values are even more important to understand, because they provide the why of a culture. If saving face or communal harmony are valued within a culture, it is certain that a negotiator will not publicly shame his company or his superior in order to succeed at the negotiation table. Likewise, a negotiator from a culture which gives greater weight to a hard-driven bargain will not necessarily be driven to settle at the earliest opportunity. Taking these generalities into consideration is important before one gets to the negotiating table. However, a negotiator is well-served to learn something about his opponent on a personal level in order to make the negotiation effective.

“The fool hath said in his heart, ‘There is no God.’” The preceding quotation is seen first in Psalm 14 of the Christian Bible, and is found at the beginning of St. Anselm’s argument regarding the existence of God. This belief seems to also be held by the other author whom we will be discussing, Thomas Aquinas. Because each of their arguments is in defense of the same concept, and our challenge is to determine who’s is the better of the two, we must, for sake of brevity, begin with the presumption that they are both correct in their belief in the existence of God, specifically the God of the Bible. To allow for a God-type figure that may not resemble the one in whom our two authors believe would not permit us to appropriately compare their two arguments, as they are essentially in defense of one specific concept of God. That being said, I would suggest that while each of them brings up valid points, neither truly provides a holistic basis for belief in God.
	To illustrate this point, we will first examine the basic argument of St. Anselm. Anselm’s passage reflects a path of gaining understanding through faith, looking within one’s self to find proof of God. He explains that because God exists within our understanding, we cannot effectively conceive his nonexistence. While this concept, when spelled out in his terminology, is a bit tedious and at times unclear, the basic gist of it is that the proof for God lies within one’s own mind. St. Anselm is suggesting to us that we needn’t go beyond the confines of our own soul to find truth about God, but that the existence of this being is found to be true simply by examining that which we inherently know to be true within our own minds. Foreign evidence is presumably unnecessary. This concept of accepting that for which there is not an irrefutable body of empirical evidence is often referred to within Christian texts as faith.
	This idea is very different from that held by St. Thomas Aquinas. Aquinas instead suggests that the existence of God can be proven entirely through reason and empirical evidence, with no need for faith of any kind. Such an idea would be beneficial in evangelism, an important element of Christianity, because it would enable the recruiting of new converts without any dependency upon their willingness to accept something that cannot be proven. They could instead be persuaded by logic alone. St. Thomas elaborates on five different logical arguments supporting the existence of God: change, causation, contingency, degrees of excellence, and harmony. In each he essentially demonstrates that the proof of God lies in the logical necessity for God. If you are told that that you are missing one puzzle piece, and assemble the rest of the puzzle, logic dictates that you can know of the features and the existence of the missing piece without having to see it.

Many authors use different ways to give their readers a certain feeling or attitude toward
important subjects. Some of these techniques are more effective than others. F. Scott Fitzgerald uses
many of these different techniques in his novel The Great Gatsby. Sometimes, Fitzgerald pairs an
adjective and a noun together that do not usually fit that way to give readers a certain aura around a
subject. Other times, he applies meaning to a symbol, and then uses it for this same purpose.
Fitzgerald uses this last technique with many colors, including gold, green, white/gray and red/pink. In
his novel The Great Gatsby F. Scott Fitzgerald builds up meaning for colors, namely white/gray and
red/pink then later uses that meaning to give readers a certain reminder of a feeling around an
important object.
The meaning Fitzgerald builds up and uses for white/gray is uniformity, with white being a bit
nicer and higher class and gray being more older and faded. Fitzgerald sets up this meaning in the
beginning of the novel with constant uses of both. Daisy and Jordan are constantly “in white” (8)—in
fact, everyone is always wearing white: Nick wears “white flannels” (41) to Gatsby’s party, Tom wears
a “white shirt” (36) when he meets Myrtle, and Catherine is “powdered milky white” (30). In fact, the
only time people are not wearing white is when Nick is getting his impressions of Gatsby’s party: “the
halls... are gaudy with primary colors” (40). Fitzgerald further defines these two colors in coloring
many common, unimportant subjects these colors: as Nick goes to work, he goes “down the white
chasms of lower New York” (56), the names of people at Gatsby’s parties are now “gray names” (61)
on Nick’s timetable, Catherine’s apartment is “one slice in a long white cake of apartment-houses”—
uniformity (28). He also describes plain or common people or places as white or gray: Jordan and
Daisy had a “white girlhood” (19) together, there are “gray cars” and “gray land” (23) in the valley of
ashes, the “Italian child” in the railroad is “gray” (26), and the dog-seller is “a gray old man” (27).
After Fitzgerald adds enough meaning to white/gray, he uses them to signify unimportance or
uniformity to certain subjects. This using colors to show readers something first starts with Daisy.
After a long time without any significant use of either of these colors, Fitzgerald comes out describing
Daisy as “dressed in white” in “a little white roadster”; readers begin to see Daisy as less of a character,
more like just a uniform addition, something that Gatsby wants and longs for (74). Fitzgerald uses
more of this technique around Daisy to give this impression of Daisy being a more uniform addition,
for example, there is a “gray haze of Daisy’s fur collar” (18), and she is again in a “white” (115) dress
before Tom and Gatsby’s encounter.

San Diego County is very agriculturally productive, thanks to a mild, sunny climate. Common crops include: tomatoes, citrus, leafy greens, squash, broccoli, herbs, tree fruits like peaches and lemons, berries, honey, and peppers. There is a substantial market for organic community supported agriculture food in the San Diego area, with many local organizations having lengthy waiting lists. Organic eggs and milk are also popular. Many organic farms also provide tours of their agricultural operations as well as access for hiking, birdwatching, and other recreational activities. This is the type of operation that would allow the landowner to gain the benefits of government programs while improving habitat, thus allowing recreational use and creating an opportunity for farm tours and other programs for making money or for educational purposes.  
	In addition to filling a potentially lucrative niche market, the benefits of organic farming often include greater biodiversity in plants and wildlife in the area thanks to a lack of chemicals in the soil and water. However, organic farming has greater costs than conventional farming in some ways. It requires more intensive labor and management to remove pests and weeds and fertilize the soil without chemicals, and losses are often greater than with conventional methods, while a small organic farm also lacks the efficiency of scale of large operations. Practices not related to organic farming but beneficial to wildlife may also incur greater labor costs, including planting cover crops, strategic grazing rotation, invasive species removal, and active management of plant growth to provide specific conditions such as edge habitat or patches of open ground. Thus, there are many reasons why the landowner in this example might seek financial help or expertise in maximizing both profits and habitat quality.  
The land chosen for this scenario is a parcel adjacent to the town of Potrero, in unincorporated San Diego County, California. It is 160 acres of chaparral, nonnative Mediterranean grassland, and oak woodland next to to the Cleveland National Forest. It lies in the East County Southern Foothills ecoregion of the San Diego Multiple Species Conservation Plan. The plan is still being reviewed, but presently considers over a hundred species of plants and animals. Many are endangered, such as the Stephens' kangaroo rat, the mountain yellow-legged frog, several species of butterfly, and the California gnatcatcher; others are declining and may soon be listed, such as burrowing owls.
	This area was inhabited by Native Americans for untold centuries and was then settled by cattle ranchers and cordwood sellers in the late 1800's. This piece of land was part of an original homestead patent and so was probably used for grazing and/or wood production for many of the intervening decades.
	 chose a piece of property from a real estate website and researched available government programs to see what options a small farmer might realistically have for mitigating costs and preserving wildlife-friendly operations.  As a model of what somebody farming this land might attempt to achieve, I located an organic farm in the same area.

There is a bond between brothers; an unbreakable, irrevocable bond. Within that bond lie many emotions: love, pride, jealousy, and cruelty, just to name a few. Brothers understand one another, far more than anyone else with that kind of bond, and they can only see themselves when looking at their brother. It is when a situation is at its most dire when the true nature of this bond shines through, be it good or evil. When these emotions become clear, they carry with them great a cost. Part of understanding the emotions born of this fraternal link is dealing with the consequences that they bring. When one can look a brother in the eye and see within that person their own reflection, they see themselves not as others see them, but as they truly are. In their actions and the consequences of those actions is where their true character lies.  In “The Scarlet Ibis”, two brothers explore this theme, and all of the raging emotions that accompany it. Throughout a lush, vividly described landscape, these two boys set out on a futile journey. Bitter disappointment clashes with intense pride in the climactic scene, and only one brother escapes with his life. The theme is expressed through direct characterization of the protagonist, Doodle, and their interactions with each other, as well as through the narrator’s point of view, which communicates the complex feelings experienced by the protagonist and his view of the world around him, both of which are heavy influences on his actions.
	The protagonist’s actions can all be summed up by one key emotion: pride. From the time he and his little brother, Doodle, first go out together, to their final, fateful excursion, the protagonist feels resentment towards Doodle. He had wanted a brother whom he could teach all of his worldly skills, like “…holding my breath, running, jumping, or climbing the vines in Old Woman Swamp…” He wanted a brother who could fill the role of “…someone to race to Horsehead Landing…and someone to perch with in the top fork of the great pine behind the barn…” Obviously these things are impossible, given Doodle’s condition. Doodle was born with an extremely weak heart, making in unlikely he would even survive. Even then, it was nearly impossible that he would ever participate in vigorous physical activity. What a blow to the young protagonist, his head filled with wild fantasies, to have all of those dreams crushed in an instant. In fact, he is even shown to bear some anger towards the small child, as he recalls beginning to contemplate killing him by suffocating him with a pillow. What kind of child would have the presence of mind to consider infanticide? However, his heart melts when the small child smiles at him. Such a simple act gave the protagonist such hope! This shows that his conviction probably was not very strong. In the back of his mind, he had an instinctive love for his brother.

The human brain is a complicated, creative information-processing system. As technology advanced from primitive to modern, the metaphors used to describe the brain also advanced. Initially, it was compared to a wax tablet, then to a sheet of papyrus, then to a book, and most recently, to a computer. As you learn about the brain, keep in mind that the usefulness of these metaphors is limited and can lead to erroneous conclusions.
Information processing starts with input from the sensory organs, which transform physical stimuli such as touch, heat, sound waves, or photons of light into electrochemical signals. The sensory information is repeatedly transformed by the algorithms of the brain in both bottom-up and top-down processing. For example, when looking at a picture of a black box on a white background, bottom-up processing puts together very simple information such as color, orientation, and where the borders of the object are – where the color changes significantly over a short space – to decide that you are seeing a box. Top-down processing uses the decisions made at some steps of the bottom-up process to speed up your recognition of the box. Top-down processing in this example might help you identify the object as a black box rather than a box-shaped hole in the white background.
Once information is processed to a degree, an attention filter decides how important the signal is and which cognitive processes it should be made available to. For example, although your brain processes every blade of grass when you look down at your shoes, a healthy attention filter prevents you from noticing them individually. In contrast, you might pick out your name, even when spoken in a noisy room. There are many stages of processing, and the results of processing are modulated by attention repeatedly.
In order for the brain to process information, it must first be stored. There are multiple types of memory, including sensory, working, and long-term. First, information is encoded. There are types of encoding specific to each type of sensory stimuli. For example, verbal input can be encoded structurally, referring to what the printed word looks like, phonemically, referring to what the word sounds like, or semantically, referring to what the word means. Once information is stored, it must be maintained. Some animal studies suggest that working memory, which stores information for roughly 20 seconds, is maintained by an electrical signal looping through a particular series of neurons for a short period of time. Information in long-term memory is hypothesized to be maintained in the structure of certain types of proteins.
There are numerous models of how the knowledge is organized in the brain, some based on the way human subjects retrieve memories, others based on computer science, and others based on neurophysiology. The semantic network model states that there are nodes representing concepts, and that the nodes are linked based on their relatedness. For example, in a semantic network, “chair” might be linked to “table,” which can be linked to “wooden,” and so forth.

In 2007, the United States of America fell into a crushing financial crisis. Unemployment increased, the housing market crashed, and many of America’s largest and most important corportations were left in ruin. This recession persists today, so we must ask the question: how did this crisis occur, and how can we stop it? In short, the financial crisis was created by selfish and naïve political decision-making that pressured banks and firms into issuing sub-prime loans into an already immature and unsufficient financial infrastructure. Meanwhile, Fannie Mae (FNMA) and Freddie Mac (FHLMC) were pressured to underwite and repackage these mortgages into CDO’s and CDS’. When borrowers defaulted on these loans, the banks were short on capital reserve and transferred this chaos onto the repacked mortgages that they had sold, and on to the rest of the economy.
	The financial crisis had its roots in 1999 of the Clinton era, as the President was aiming for a second term in office. He sought to extend his presidential tenure by augmenting his popularity. To accomplish this the Clinton administration relaxed lending restrictions, which helped to set the grim stage for the sub-prime crisis seven years later.  Steven Holmes of the New York Times reported in 1999, “Fannie Mae, the nation's biggest underwriter of home mortgages, has been under increasing pressure from the Clinton Administration to expand mortgage loans among low and moderate income people and felt pressure from stock holders to maintain its phenomenal growth in profits.” Holmes would go on to correctly foresee the consequences of these actions: “But the government-subsidized corporation may run into trouble in an economic downturn, prompting a government rescue similar to that of the savings and loan industry in the 1980s.” As detailed in the introduction, and as Holmes foresaw, ill-advised lending would certainly lead to the meltdown of the economy.
	Many factors combined to throw the economy into tailspin, one of which was the new and complex structure of mortgages. Adjustable-rate mortgages, mortgage-backed securities, and collateralized debt obligations (CDO’s) were all used extensively in the years leading up to the crisis, and only served to intertwine more sectors of the economy into the housing market. This led to U.S. households, and financial markets in general, to overleverage themselves in the housing market, leaving them extremely vulnerable to even small changes in price. 
	Indeed, the housing bubble burst, and the financial institutions that had bought these mortgage-backed securities were spited. The top five U.S. investment banks all together reported $4.1 trillion dollars of mortgage debts in 2007, which accounted for about 30% of the USA’s GDP. In the end, Bear Sterns and Merrill Lynch were sold exceptionally cheap, Lehman Brothers was dismantled, and Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley were forced to become commercial banks subjected to intense regulation. Fannie and Freddie were $5 trillion in mortgage debt, and were placed under government control in September 2008.

Ah, exposition.  That place in your story where you stretch your little writer's wings and take flight, astounding one and all with your magnetic, nay magical prose.  Or the part where your readers fall asleep and/or hit the "Back" button while cursing your name.  Dr. Merlin has been known to shout at her monitor when she finds herself in the middle of Too Much Information, and not even in the fun way.

Exposition is not your friend.

My gentle readers already know the basic writing tip, "Show, don't tell," but Dr. Merlin still stumbles into long passages of text where nothing happens, or worse, too much.  Exposition is the little devil sitting on your shoulder that says to get the history out of the way to get to the good parts (not to be confused with the devil sitting on the other shoulder urging the author to tell her audience every single detail of the childhoods of each character).

Exposition means telling the audience what happened, typically in simple prose.  In film, the exposition happens when one character tells another a core-dump of information ala "The Rime of the Ancient Mariner."  In fiction, the author's doing the telling.

An example is in order.  As you are reading a story, you are told that the heroine met her beloved at such a place and time, that they were married in a gala fashion, and that her husband was murdered in front of her eyes.  You would not expect this entire sequence to take two pages, during which time both he and she only get two lines of dialogue each.  You would expect the author to spend some time on the husband's character, evidencing by his speech and manner how deeply he loves his wife, and you would equally expect the heroine to show through big and small ways how much his presence in her life changed and enriched her (especially if the story were to tell you flat out later that this was the case).  A proper introduction to the husband's character would allow you to become emotionally involved with his fate and would give you insight into the heroine's character: what she saw in him, how deep their bond was, clues about her thoughts and beliefs and dreams as reflected through the prism of his eyes, and so on.  You would mourn his death with her, and so grow more connected to the heroine herself.

In short, you would expect meat on the simple bone of the storyline: "They met, they married, he died."

As a writer, you need to provide that meat.  (*looks at metaphor, sighs, plunges onward*)  Sometimes it is tempting to rush past certain things.  Perhaps you're introducing a new character and you know he used to be in the Air Force, and he's the night manager of a gas station now, and he was married twice, no kids, likes to go fishing on the weekends, secretly dreams of owning the gas station someday and had Eggs Benedict for breakfast.

I watched two newscast’s from Columbus, Ohio. The first one that was “live” was NBC 4 this morning (August 13, 2011). The lead story was about a man in Ashley, Ohio who had stabbed his wife, it did not state her name however his name was Shad Hostettler. They showed his mug shot and he looked like pure evil. They devoted only about two minutes to this story as it was developing. The only details they provide he had stabbed her multiple times and had been arrested. I think they spent an appropriate amount of time on this story. 
	The second story was about an early morning shooting of Travis Buyers, 18. He was shot in the Sharon Woods area and had been critically injured; there had been no arrests made at the time or any suspects. The SWAT Team was investigating the crime. This story seemed to be short, and I believe that might have been due to the fact this was a “black” man or a black neighborhood. I noticed (and have for years) that minorities are glossed over when they are a victim of a crime. If say a “white” child or adult is kidnapped or missing or a victim of a crime the media goes nuts; but if a minority person it’s lucky if it is even mentioned. 
	The next story was about the gunshot hole that had been found in the Med-Flight helicopter. Details were given about where they thought the incident happened. It had been determined that it was a .22 caliber bullet from a rifle that had hit the helicopter. Crime-Stoppers are offering a five-thousand dollar reward for tips that lead to the arrest of the shooter. 
	The next story was concerning the rain and thunderstorms predicted for Saturday afternoon. They said the temperatures would remain in the mid to low eighties for the weekend. The length of time was a little short, but they wanted to use it as a “teaser” so that you would stay tuned. 
	They also ran with a story about a robbery of a Clime Road UDF in Columbus. They said it was dark-skinned black man who robbed the store he was wearing a hoodie sweatshirt. They said he was about six-foot tall and weighed about one hundred and fifty pounds. I thought they devoted an unusual about of time emphasizing he was black and how dark he was. 
	Another story was about a Rene Rodriguez who was a convicted Texas Drug-Kingpin. He had been convicted of conspiring to distribute marijuana in large amounts to Ohio from Texas. One curious thing I noted, was instead of saying he was sentenced to twenty-five years in prison they said “300” months. I am not sure what the angle was there, whether they thought that sounded more harsh or what. They also mentioned he was a Hispanic man, I don’t believe that was really germane to the story.

An ETF, or exchange traded fund, is a security that is designed to track an index, a commodity or a basket of assets like an index fund, but is more flexible and trades like a stock on an exchange.  An ETF gives you the diversification of an index fund and the benefits of single stock ownership like the ability to sell short, buy on margin and purchase as few as a one share in any transaction.  Though these benefits are extremely attractive, the expense ratios of ETFs are far lower than those of the average mutual fund.  Unfortunately, there are some down sides, such as the need to pay a commission on any trade involving ETFs, just as you would pay on a stock order.  Another benefit of ETFs is the wide variety of funds available.  Though these benefits are clearly stated, it is always a good exercise for the savvy financial investor to evaluate whether stated benefits, like diversification, do indeed exist, and the extent to which they exist.  For the purposes of this effort, we will be examining the ETF IHF and comparing it against the top 10 holdings that comprise the ETF to determine whether the benefits of a owning a single ETF come close to the benefits of owning a diversified portfolio of the ten stocks and also whether or not there are better configurations of the same stocks that would provide a more optimal sharp ratio or return.
	In order to evaluate the ETF, it would become rather unwieldy to include every holding, therefore we have decided to include only the top ten holdings accounting for 63.58% of all the assets in the ETF.  Below are the top 10 holdings and the percentage of total assets.

	In order to gain an estimation of how well these ten stocks represent the ETF IHF as a whole, we can use the current % of assets, normalized to 100%, to  calculate the contributions of each stock to a portfolioâ€™s Beta and Return if the portfolio was made up entirely of these 10 stocks in the proportion that the ETF has established through their holdings.
